database_metadata.description: Curated dataset of global venues classified as Tourist Traps, Local Gems, or Mixed, with embeddings for RAG retrieval. Combined from rag_v3.json and 4 expansion batches.

entries.name: Caffè Florian
entries.summary: The oldest coffee house in the world offering undeniable history and stunning interiors, but marred by astronomical prices (music surcharge + €12 coffees) and generally dismissed by modern travelers as a 'one-time' bucket list tax rather than a quality culinary experience.

red_flags.description: Exorbitant surcharges for music and basic items
red_flags.evidence: "They'll make you pay €5 more just for some live music... real thieves." (Reddit)

red_flags.description: Relying entirely on St. Mark's Square location
red_flags.evidence: "Universally acknowledged as paying for location not quality." (Travel Forums)

positive_signals.evidence: "You can breathe the long and lively history... comfortable seated in magnificent halls." (Website/Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Skip Cafe Florian (they are some real thieves, they'll make you pay 5€ more just for some live music).
It's one of those 'bucket list' spots, but just go in knowing what to expect... overpriced but you get an experience.

entries.embedding_text: Caffè Florian in Venice, Italy. cafe. tourist_trap. The oldest coffee house in the world offering undeniable history, but marred by astronomical prices and music surcharges. Red flags: Exorbitant surcharges, Relying entirely on St. Mark's Square location. Positives: Historical significance is genuine.

entries.name: Harry's Bar
entries.summary: Inventors of the Bellini, but the reality is often cramped seating, indifferent service, and astronomically priced drinks (€20-30). It survives on its Hemingway connection, dividing visitors between those who feel ripped off and those who value the legacy.

red_flags.description: Extremely expensive cocktails for the quality
red_flags.evidence: "Threw away my money on the really bad 12 Euro drink... costs way more than its worth." (Fodor's)

red_flags.description: Staff described as snobbish or indifferent
red_flags.evidence: "Snotty waiters... poor service... snapping fingers." (Fodor's)

positive_signals.evidence: "Since they invented them, you won't find a better one anywhere else." (Travel Forum)

sample_reviews.text: I went, I saw, but I would never go back... If you want good food and drink at fair prices then I would not go there.
It is a neat, historic place and a nice spot to chill out for a bit... I suggest you should [go], otherwise you'll probably feel like you missed something.

entries.embedding_text: Harry's Bar in Venice, Italy. bar. mixed. Inventors of the Bellini, but the reality is often cramped seating, indifferent service, and astronomically priced drinks. Red flags: Extremely expensive cocktails, Staff described as snobbish. Positives: The original Bellini source.

entries.name: Osteria al Squero
entries.summary: A genuine Venetian experience serving affordable cicchetti directly opposite a gondola workshop. Despite growing popularity, it maintains high quality, fair prices, and strong local endorsement.

red_flags.evidence: "Usually has a queue but deserve the time." (Google Reviews)

positive_signals.description: Widely cited as a local favorite
positive_signals.evidence: "My favorite stop for far for local food... People know about this place." (Google Reviews)
"Good value for the money! For €10 you will have two or three small local bocadillos." (Google Reviews)

positive_signals.description: Unique view of San Trovaso Gondola boatyard
positive_signals.evidence: "Sipping Spritz while watching gondolas being repaired is a unique experience." (Wanderlog)

sample_reviews.text: What a nice little gem! The service was really quick... Tasty, vegetarian options, good portion size.
SO MUCH BETTER than the 'more famous' schiavi down the walk... Has seats and fresh made.

entries.embedding_text: Osteria al Squero in Venice, Italy. bar. local_gem. A genuine Venetian experience serving affordable cicchetti opposite a gondola workshop. Maintains high quality and fair prices. Red flags: Crowding can be an issue. Positives: Widely cited as local favorite, Excellent price-to-quality, Unique view of Gondola boatyard.

entries.name: Ristorante Carlo Menta
entries.summary: A divisive venue that operates on a 'volume trap' model—very cheap 'tourist menus' (€10-13) that attract hordes. While food snobs decry the mass-produced quality, budget travelers and some locals defend it as an unbeatable value option in a pricey neighborhood.

red_flags.evidence: "Lasagna is a great let-down... hardly any béchamel... pasta glued into a slab." (Dine&Discover)
"Partner was hit twice by the server moving through the narrow tables." (Wanderlog)

positive_signals.evidence: "Prices are refreshingly honest: pizzas from €2–3, generous pastas for around €5–7." (Italian Food Guide)

sample_reviews.text: The food here really was so good... The prices were very reasonable... We came back twice.
The lasagna is a great let-down... basically just 10 sheets of pasta glued into a slab.

entries.embedding_text: Ristorante Carlo Menta in Rome, Italy. restaurant. mixed. A divisive venue operating on a 'volume trap' model with very cheap tourist menus. Budget travelers defend the value, while snobs decry the mass-produced quality. Red flags: Mass-produced lower quality food, Chaotic environment. Positives: Extremely cheap for the location.

entries.name: Tonnarello
entries.summary: The epicenter of Trastevere's Instagram scene. Massive queues and social media fame scream 'trap', yet the food (Carbonara/Cacio e Pepe) consistently receives high marks for flavor and portion size, even from skeptics.

red_flags.evidence: "Destroyed by mass tourism and bloggers... tourist hordes." (Reddit)
"Overcrowded and rushed." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Without a doubt one of the best restaurants in Rome... food is absolutely delicious." (Backpacker's World)

sample_reviews.text: If you don't have time to read the whole review... Tonnarello is without a doubt one of the best restaurants in Rome.
Destroyed by mass tourism... just overcrowded and rushed.

entries.embedding_text: Tonnarello in Rome, Italy. restaurant. mixed. The epicenter of Trastevere's Instagram scene. Massive queues scream 'trap', yet the food (Carbonara) consistently receives high marks. Red flags: Overwhelmed by tourists, Factory-like turnover. Positives: Food quality holds up.

entries.name: Da Enzo al 29
entries.summary: Perhaps the most famous 'authentic' trattoria in Rome. The line is brutal (often 1-2 hours), but the food—specifically the Carbonara and Fried Artichokes—is universally acknowledged as the gold standard.

red_flags.evidence: "Be prepared to join a very long queue." (Time Out)

positive_signals.evidence: "The seasonal, deep-fried Jewish artichokes and the pasta cacio e pepe... are among the best in Rome." (Lonely Planet)
"Everything you would imagine a classic Roman trattoria to be." (Fodor's)

sample_reviews.text: The best restaurant in Rome is (actually) worth the hour-long queue.
Don't expect a long, leisurely experience... space is limited... and service is fast and furious.

entries.embedding_text: Da Enzo al 29 in Rome, Italy. restaurant. local_gem. Famous authentic trattoria in Rome. Despite brutal lines, the food (Carbonara, Fried Artichokes) is acknowledged as the gold standard. Red flags: Extreme wait times. Positives: Best-in-class dishes, Retains authentic character.

entries.name: Pizzarium Bonci
entries.summary: Gabriele Bonci's pizza masterpiece has become a victim of its own Netflix success. While the topping creativity is unmatched, recent reports consistently cite 'absurd' prices (€20+ for lunch) and a loss of the original local soul.

red_flags.evidence: "Utterly disappointed... pizza slices weren't that good and it cost me 22 Euros." (Reddit)
"Almost no Italians and definitely no locals queue up there." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Many people swear by it... as among the best pizza in the world." (YouTube Review)

sample_reviews.text: It is good but also overhyped... absurdly overpriced for something you can find in literally every block.
I enjoyed the slices... it was great to tick off the list.

entries.embedding_text: Pizzarium Bonci in Rome, Italy. street_food. mixed. Gabriele Bonci's pizza masterpiece is a victim of Netflix success. Unmatched creativity, but locals cite absurd prices and loss of soul. Red flags: Very expensive for street food, Locals priced out. Positives: Innovation in toppings.

entries.name: Café de Flore
entries.summary: High prices (€15 coffee) and a clientele of 90% tourists make this a trap by definition. The history is real, but you are paying a massive premium purely for the name and the photo op.

red_flags.evidence: "€15 for a coffee is a tax on tourists." (Lemon8)
"Tour groups shuffle past every five minutes." (Paris Playbook)

positive_signals.evidence: "Underneath all the performance... there's still a functioning piece of Parisian history." (Paris Playbook)

sample_reviews.text: The prices are high, not reasonable. But the atmosphere genuinely delivers.
I struggled with the pricing... but it was a highlight of my Paris trip.

entries.embedding_text: Café de Flore in Paris, France. cafe. tourist_trap. High prices (€15 coffee) and 90% tourists make this a trap. The history is real, but you pay a massive premium for the name and photo op. Red flags: Extreme markup for standard items, Dominated by tourists. Positives: Historic interior remains authentic.

entries.name: L'As du Fallafel
entries.summary: Despite the Lenny Kravitz endorsement and long lines, the falafel pita remains a benchmark for quality in the Marais. The line moves fast, prices are reasonable, and the product delivers.

red_flags.evidence: "Line was insane and underwhelming af." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The very best falafel pita of my life. Love everything about this place." (Airial Travel)

positive_signals.description: Good value if you do takeout
positive_signals.evidence: "Portions are large; consider sharing." (Airial Travel)

sample_reviews.text: The very best falafel pita of my life... worth the wait.
I found the falafel kinda bland tbh... line was insane.

entries.embedding_text: L'As du Fallafel in Paris, France. street_food. local_gem. Despite endorsements and long lines, the falafel pita remains a benchmark for quality in the Marais. Reasonable prices and the product delivers. Red flags: Chaotic queues. Positives: Best in class food, Good value.

entries.name: La Mère Poulard
entries.summary: Infamous for charging €35-50 for an omelette. While the wood-fire cooking spectacle is unique, the consensus is that the food quality does not justify the luxury price tag, making it a classic 'paying for the name' trap.

red_flags.evidence: "34 Euro for an omelet [2017 price]... debate goes on whether the omelet is worth the price." (David Lebovitz)
"1/4 cup of melted butter left in my plate... dining room was like a bus station." (David Lebovitz comments)

positive_signals.evidence: "Anyone can watch the omelets being made over the open fire." (David Lebovitz)

sample_reviews.text: Considering the ambiance... I'd pay it. It was a highlight.
Dining room was like a bus station... mediocre yet overpriced.

entries.embedding_text: La Mère Poulard in Mont Saint-Michel, France. restaurant. tourist_trap. Infamous for charging €35-50 for an omelette. While the wood-fire cooking spectacle is unique, the food quality does not justify the luxury price tag. Red flags: Extreme pricing for simple eggs, Underwhelming execution. Positives: Historic preparation method.

entries.name: Pink Mamma
entries.summary: A visually stunning venue built for Instagram. While the decor is undeniable, it is strictly an 'influencer trap' that Parisians avoid due to bland food and a manufactured atmosphere.

red_flags.evidence: "Pink Mama was disappointingly bland and unimpressive... not worth going to." (Reddit)
"Just another brasserie... Parisians do not eat there, like ever." (Reddit)

positive_signals.description: Not overly expensive for the location
positive_signals.evidence: "A bit expensive but it's not a bad place at all." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Beautiful building and fun inside but not worth going to. Disappointingly bland.
It's a bit expensive but it's not a bad place at all.

entries.embedding_text: Pink Mamma in Paris, France. restaurant. tourist_trap. Visually stunning venue built for Instagram. Strictly an 'influencer trap' that Parisians avoid due to bland food and manufactured atmosphere. Red flags: Food secondary to visuals, Parisians do not eat here. Positives: Not overly expensive.

entries.name: Le Bouillon Chartier
entries.summary: A historic institution offering incredibly cheap meals (€11 steak frites) in a Belle Époque setting. It is a 'Food Trap' (quality is often described as cafeteria-level) but a 'Price/Experience Gem'. You go for the vibe and the bill, not the gastronomy.

red_flags.description: Low quality ingredients despite low price
red_flags.evidence: "The food at Bouillons is the lowest quality possible... tasted like paper." (Reddit)
"Dining room was like a bus station." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "French staples at a (very) reasonable price... steak with fries for just 11.40€." (Urbansider)
"Spectacular Art Nouveau setting... last living remnants of Paris in the Belle Epoque." (Urbansider)

sample_reviews.text: It's fun and it's cheap but the food sucks. It's not that much of a tourist trap, it's just a popular bouillon.
Perfect place if you want simple, classic French cuisine at an unbeatable price.

entries.embedding_text: Le Bouillon Chartier in Paris, France. restaurant. mixed. Historic institution offering incredibly cheap meals in a Belle Époque setting. A 'Food Trap' but 'Price Gem'. You go for the vibe and bill, not gastronomy. Red flags: Low quality ingredients, Rushed dining. Positives: Unbeatable prices, Historic atmosphere.

entries.name: Restaurant La Poma
entries.summary: Located on Las Ramblas, this venue fits the visual profile of a tourist trap. While some robotic service gimmicks amuse tourists, food quality varies wildly and it relies entirely on foot traffic rather than repeat customers.

red_flags.evidence: "Some find the long lines appealing, others feel it doesn't live up to hype." (Wanderlog)

positive_signals.description: Staff can be helpful despite chaos
positive_signals.evidence: "Staff and service is amazing... Luis was extremely helpful." (Wanderlog)

sample_reviews.text: The food was good, albeit too flavourful but the staff and service is amazing.
Waiters are not reactive... It's a pity because the food is good.

entries.embedding_text: Restaurant La Poma in Barcelona, Spain. restaurant. tourist_trap. Located on Las Ramblas, fits the profile of a trap. Relies on foot traffic, food quality varies wildly. Red flags: Las Ramblas location suggests trap. Positives: Staff can be helpful.

entries.name: El Xampanyet
entries.summary: A chaotic, standing-room-only institution in El Born that remains beloved by locals despite being in every guide book. The house cava and anchovies are legendary, and the atmosphere is authentic Catalan energy.

red_flags.evidence: "You may have to struggle a little to get a table... small and noisy, a real mess!" (Vinparleur)

positive_signals.evidence: "Tourists and locals mingle here... popularity is well-deserved." (Vinparleur)
"Tapas are fresh and excellent! ... You will leave with the feeling of having tasted 'real' Barcelona." (Vinparleur)

sample_reviews.text: Just try them all, even if you do not understand everything on the menu, because every bite is worth it.
Crowded, colorful and popular... a real mess! But before all, the tapas are fresh and excellent!

entries.embedding_text: El Xampanyet in Barcelona, Spain. bar. local_gem. Chaotic, standing-room-only institution in El Born beloved by locals. House cava and anchovies are legendary. Authentic Catalan energy. Red flags: Extremely crowded/Noisy. Positives: Locals still go, Excellent tapas.

entries.name: La Boqueria (Front Stalls)
entries.summary: The entrance to La Boqueria is a designated 'tourist exploitation zone' selling pre-cut fruit and smoothies at 300% markup. Real foodies know to push past the first 20 meters to find the actual market stalls.

red_flags.evidence: "Front stalls are pure tourist exploitation – €12 fruit cups that cost €3 anywhere else." (Cruise Blog)
"Jamón displays designed for Instagram rather than eating." (Cruise Blog)

positive_signals.description: The back of the market is still valid
positive_signals.evidence: "Venture to the back where Quim de la Boqueria does creative stuff." (Cruise Blog)

sample_reviews.text: This market honestly is ridiculous... prices are higher for tourists [at front stalls].
Avoid Front Stalls... Go Deeper Inside. Explore beyond the initial stalls.

entries.embedding_text: La Boqueria (Front Stalls) in Barcelona, Spain. market. tourist_trap. The entrance is a designated 'tourist exploitation zone' selling pre-cut fruit at 300% markup. Real foodies push past the first 20 meters. Red flags: Huge markups at entrance, Designed for photos not eating. Positives: The back of the market is still valid.

entries.name: Bar Pinotxo
entries.summary: Historically a legend, but marred by a recent bitter family dispute and change of ownership/location. While some still recommend the new iteration for early breakfasts, others cite a decline in soul and food quality compared to the Juanito era.

red_flags.evidence: "Disappointed by Bar Pinotxo... blood sausage didn't add as much flavor... tiring and dry." (Food Blog)

positive_signals.evidence: "Mushroom croquettes... definitely a top bite for the trip." (Food Blog)

sample_reviews.text: The squid was cooked just right... heavenly.
I'd say I was disappointed... certainly something I could make at home.

entries.embedding_text: Bar Pinotxo in Barcelona, Spain. restaurant. mixed. Historically a legend, but marred by a recent family dispute and change of ownership. Some cite decline in soul and quality, others still recommend. Red flags: Mixed reviews on food. Positives: Specific dishes still praised.

entries.name: Angus Steakhouse
entries.summary: The ultimate London tourist trap, now the subject of a massive Reddit prank where locals 'lovebomb' it with fake positive reviews to confuse AI and influencers. In reality, it serves mediocre, overpriced steak to tourists who don't know better.

red_flags.evidence: "Londoners are leaving ultra-positive reviews... in a bid to stop their favourite eating spots being swamped." (News Report)
"Steak was tough and flavorless, clearly not fresh." (TripAdvisor)

red_flags.description: Locals use it as a punchline
red_flags.evidence: "For decades, Angus Steakhouse was a London punchline." (YouTube)

positive_signals.evidence: "Reddit users have hailed the chain... as a 'little-known gem'." (Satire/News)

sample_reviews.text: Angus Steakhouse does an awesome steak sandwich. Influencers should try it and be amazed. (Note: This is satire/fake)
It's a tourist trap... mediocre food.

entries.embedding_text: Angus Steakhouse in London, UK. restaurant. tourist_trap. Ultimate London tourist trap, subject of a Reddit prank where locals 'lovebomb' it with fake reviews. In reality, serves mediocre, overpriced steak. Red flags: Subject of satirical campaign, Locals use it as punchline, Generic frozen ingredients. Positives: FAKE positive signals exist.

entries.name: Dishoom
entries.summary: A rare example of a chain that maintains soul. Modeled on Irani cafes of Bombay, it draws massive queues of both tourists and Londoners because the food (Black Daal, Bacon Naan) is consistently excellent and reasonably priced.

red_flags.evidence: "Dishoom is mostly a walk-in café... queues can be lengthy." (Official Site/Reviews)

positive_signals.evidence: "Hidden gems, lovely histories, the most delicious comfort food." (Dishoom Site/General Consensus)
"Succulent prawns... fiery-sweet-tangy tomato masala." (Dishoom Menu/Review)

sample_reviews.text: The most delicious comfort food and countless stories to be told.

entries.embedding_text: Dishoom in London, UK. restaurant. local_gem. Rare example of a chain that maintains soul. Draws massive queues of tourists and locals because food (Black Daal) is consistently excellent and reasonably priced. Red flags: Long queues. Positives: Londoners love it, Iconic dishes.

entries.name: Rainforest Cafe (Piccadilly)
entries.summary: A 'theme' restaurant where you pay for animatronic elephants rather than food. Reviews consistently mention lukewarm, expensive dishes with 'exotic' names that mask mediocrity. Purely for children, a culinary wasteland for adults.

red_flags.evidence: "Vegetables were good but the broth was anything but rich and zesty." (Dine Online)
"It's a gift shop that serves burgers. The noise level is unbearable." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "He quite liked them (kids are so fussy!)." (Dine Online)

sample_reviews.text: Ten out of ten for the sauce... meat loaf didn't taste of anything very recognisable.
highlights: ten out of ten for sauce

sample_reviews.text: Prices have been reduced for London, which says a lot about American appetites!

entries.embedding_text: Rainforest Cafe (Piccadilly) in London, UK. restaurant. tourist_trap. Theme restaurant where you pay for animatronics. Reviews mention lukewarm, expensive dishes masking mediocrity. Culinary wasteland for adults. Red flags: Expensive poor quality food, Chaotic noisy environment. Positives: Good for kids.

entries.name: Borough Market
entries.summary: A world-class market struggling with its own viral fame. While stalls like the chocolate-covered strawberries are now deemed 'tourist traps' due to influencers, the core market (cheese, bread, produce) remains high quality, though crowded and pricey.

red_flags.evidence: "Sea of people just standing there with their phone up." (Reddit)
"That strawberry and chocolate stand is an absolute rip off." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Borough Market sells actually good things... surrounded by brilliant restaurants." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: A tourist trap is an attraction that isn't actually good... Borough Market sells actually good things. The exception is those fucking strawberries.
Couldn't pay me to go there now it's dreadful.

entries.embedding_text: Borough Market in London, UK. market. mixed. World-class market struggling with viral fame. Viral items (strawberries) are traps, but core market (cheese, bread) remains high quality. Red flags: Overrun by influencers, Viral items are rip-offs. Positives: Genuine food quality remains.

entries.name: Olive Garden Times Square
entries.summary: The ultimate NYC tourist trap. Visitors pay a massive premium (prices ~$10 higher than suburban locations) for the exact same frozen, microwaved food served at any mall in America, purely for a view of the billboards.

red_flags.evidence: "Paying $30 for pasta that costs $12 in Ohio just to look at crowds." (Reddit)
"Going to NYC and eating here is a culinary crime." (Eater NY)

positive_signals.evidence: "Worth buying a soda just to use a clean bathroom in the middle of the chaos." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: If you are from the US, why are you here? It's the same food but double the price. A total trap.
We sat by the window and watched the ball drop. Food was standard but view was worth it.

entries.embedding_text: Olive Garden Times Square in New York, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Ultimate NYC tourist trap. Massive premium for same frozen food served at any mall. Red flags: Standard chain food at 200% markup, Zero local culture. Positives: Clean bathrooms in Times Square.

entries.name: Katz's Delicatessen
entries.summary: Chaotic, expensive ($25+ sandwich), and filled with tourists reenacting 'When Harry Met Sally'. However, unlike many traps, the pastrami is still hand-carved and widely considered the benchmark for the city, earning it begrudging respect from locals.

red_flags.evidence: "$28 for a sandwich is aggressive, even for NYC." (Infatuation)
"Lose your ticket and you pay $50. The anxiety ruins the meal." (Yelp)

positive_signals.evidence: "Despite the tourists, it is still the king of meats. The cutter gives you a sample." (Serious Eats)
"It smells, looks, and sounds like it did 50 years ago." (New York Times)

sample_reviews.text: Touristy? Yes. Expensive? Yes. Best pastrami of my life? Also yes. Just follow the rules with the ticket.
I can't justify waiting 45 mins and paying nearly $30 for a sandwich when 2nd Ave Deli exists.

entries.embedding_text: Katz's Delicatessen in New York, USA. restaurant. mixed. Chaotic, expensive, filled with tourists. However, hand-carved pastrami is still considered the benchmark. Red flags: Very expensive for a sandwich, Confusing ticket system. Positives: World-class pastrami, Genuine historic institution.

entries.name: Hollywood Walk of Fame
entries.summary: Consistently voted one of the world's worst tourist attractions. Visitors expect glamour but find a dirty, crowded sidewalk filled with aggressive CD hustlers, costumed scammers, and zero Hollywood magic.

red_flags.evidence: "Smells like urine, crowded, and honestly just a sidewalk." (Reddit)
"Don't take the CDs. Don't take photos with Spiderman unless you want to be shaken down." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's iconic. You go, take a picture of your favorite star, and leave immediately." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: The most disappointing landmark in America. Grimy, crowded, and nothing to see but names on the floor.
Avoid at all costs. It's just a dirty street with people trying to scam you.

entries.embedding_text: Hollywood Walk of Fame in Los Angeles, USA. attraction. tourist_trap. Consistently voted one of world's worst attractions. Dirty, crowded sidewalk filled with aggressive CD hustlers and scammers. Red flags: Dirty and unsafe feeling, Aggressive hustlers. Positives: Iconic photo op.

entries.name: Peter Luger Steak House
entries.summary: Once the undisputed king of NYC steak, it is now a battleground. While the porterhouse remains high quality, the cash-only policy, notoriously rude service (once charming, now seen as hostile), and 0-star NYT review have shifted it toward 'trap' territory for many.

red_flags.evidence: "The service isn't 'charming curmudgeon' anymore, it's just neglectful and rude." (NYT Review)
"Refusing credit cards in 2024 at $100/head is purely arrogant." (Yelp)

positive_signals.description: Steak is still top tier for some
positive_signals.evidence: "The porterhouse is still the benchmark against which all others are measured." (Eater NY)

sample_reviews.text: It feels like they are doing you a favor by letting you eat there. The steak was good, but not worth the abuse.
Ignore the haters. The burger at lunch is the best deal in the city.

entries.embedding_text: Peter Luger Steak House in New York, USA. restaurant. mixed. Once undisputed king of NYC steak, now controversial. Porterhouse remains high quality, but cash-only policy and rude service shift it toward 'trap'. Red flags: Hostile service, Cash/Debit only. Positives: Steak is still top tier for some.

entries.name: Cafe Du Monde
entries.summary: Open 24/7, this is a rare tourist spot that locals defend. The line is long and the menu is tiny (beignets + coffee), but the prices remain low and the product is fresh and consistent. It's crowded, but not a rip-off.

red_flags.evidence: "Powdered sugar everywhere, sticky tables, and a line down the block." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Three beignets for under $4 is the best inflation-proof treat in the city." (NOLA Eater)
"Locals go at 2 AM to avoid the lines. It hits different late at night." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: It's a tourist trap in the sense that everyone goes there, but it's cheap and the beignets are actually amazing.
Don't wait in the line. Just walk in and grab a dirty table like a local.

entries.embedding_text: Cafe Du Monde in New Orleans, USA. cafe. mixed. Open 24/7, rare tourist spot locals defend. Long lines, but low prices and fresh product. Red flags: Always crowded/dirty tables. Positives: Cheap and delicious, Late night staple.

entries.name: Oceana Grill
entries.summary: Infamous among locals for aggressive street hustlers, hygiene issues (featured on Kitchen Nightmares), and suing anyone who leaves a bad review. It relies on Bourbon Street foot traffic and tourists who don't know better.

red_flags.evidence: "Locals call it the stomach ache waiting to happen. Pest control issues are public record." (Reddit)
"They sue reviewers. That tells you everything you need to know." (Eater NOLA)

positive_signals.evidence: "Good if you have a huge bachelor party and everyone else is booked." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Do not eat here. The food was cold, and the place smelled like sewage. Locals avoid this place like the plague.
The crab cakes were decent, but the service felt like they were trying to turn the table in 30 minutes.

entries.embedding_text: Oceana Grill in New Orleans, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Infamous for aggressive street hustlers, hygiene issues, and suing reviewers. Relies on Bourbon Street foot traffic. Red flags: History of health violations, Aggressive legal threats. Positives: Open late/Large groups.

entries.name: Bubba Gump Shrimp Co.
entries.summary: The archetype of a chain tourist trap. Located on Fisherman's Wharf, it serves mostly deep-fried frozen seafood at premium prices. You pay for the Forrest Gump trivia and the view, not the food.

red_flags.evidence: "Rubber shrimp. You are in San Francisco, surrounded by fresh seafood, eating frozen Sysco bags." (SF Gate)
"The trivia quiz by the waiter is agonizing." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "If you get a window seat, the view of the bridge is actually nice." (Google Maps)

sample_reviews.text: Why go here? You are in SF! Go to Swan Oyster Depot. This is like eating at a mall food court with a view.
Kids loved the movie references. Food was okay, nothing special, but good family fun.

entries.embedding_text: Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. in San Francisco, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Archetype of chain trap on Fisherman's Wharf. Deep-fried frozen seafood at premium prices. You pay for the trivia and view. Red flags: Frozen food at fresh prices, Corporate theme park dining. Positives: Bay views.

entries.name: La Taqueria
entries.summary: Home of the rice-free Mission Burrito and a James Beard award winner. Despite lines of tourists, locals remain fiercely loyal to the 'El Dorado' style burritos. It manages the volume without sacrificing quality.

red_flags.evidence: "Line moves fast but it wraps around the building on weekends." (Eater SF)

positive_signals.evidence: "No rice filler, just meat, beans, and salsa. The golden standard." (FiveThirtyEight)
"I've been coming here for 20 years. The carne asada is still the best." (Yelp)

sample_reviews.text: Best burrito in the world. Get it dorado style (crispy). Worth every minute of the wait.
It's expensive for a burrito ($15+) but it's huge and all meat. No rice filler makes a difference.

entries.embedding_text: La Taqueria in San Francisco, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Home of the rice-free Mission Burrito and James Beard winner. Locals remain fiercely loyal to 'El Dorado' style burritos. Red flags: Long lines. Positives: Rice-free burrito innovation, Neighborhood staple.

entries.name: Bacchanal Buffet
entries.summary: The most famous buffet in Vegas comes with a staggering price tag ($80+) and strict time limits. However, the sheer variety and quality of ingredients (wagyu sliders, crab legs) separate it from standard casino troughs. It's an 'Experience Trap'—expensive, but delivers on the promise.

red_flags.evidence: "By the time you pay tax and tip, it's $100 per person for a buffet." (Vegas Eater)
"They rush you out after 90 minutes. Not a relaxing meal." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "This isn't old shrimp... it's fresh crab, wagyu, and countless cuisines cooked well." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Is it worth $80? Probably not. Is it the best buffet I've ever been to? Yes. Go hungry.
We felt herded like cattle. Food was good but the line to get in took an hour even with a reservation.

entries.embedding_text: Bacchanal Buffet in Las Vegas, USA. restaurant. mixed. Most famous buffet in Vegas. Staggering price ($80+) and strict time limits, but variety and quality (wagyu, crab) separate it from standard troughs. Red flags: Extremely high price point, Time limits. Positives: High-end ingredients.

entries.name: Heart Attack Grill
entries.summary: A restaurant built entirely on shock value. Diners wear hospital gowns and are spanked by waitresses if they don't finish their 'Bypass Burgers'. The food is greasy and mediocre; you are paying to be part of a spectacle.

red_flags.evidence: "The burger was dry and tasteless. You go for the weird spanking fetish, not the food." (Reddit)
"It's just gross. Watching people over 350lbs eat for free is depressing." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's a one-time thing for the story." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Disgusting food, disgusting concept. I felt sick just being there.
It's hilarious if you have a dark sense of humor. Don't expect gourmet, expect a show.

entries.embedding_text: Heart Attack Grill in Las Vegas, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Built on shock value. Diners wear hospital gowns. Food is greasy and mediocre; you pay for the spectacle. Red flags: Gimmick over quality, Uncomfortable atmosphere. Positives: Unique (if morbid) experience.

entries.name: Sky Bar at Lebua
entries.summary: Made famous by 'The Hangover II', this rooftop bar is now a chaotic photo-op factory. Staff aggressively push overpriced champagne, there is nowhere to sit, and security herds guests like cattle to keep walkways clear.

red_flags.evidence: "$35 for a watered-down mocktail in a plastic cup? Criminal." (TripAdvisor)
"You are yelled at if you stop moving. It's not a bar, it's a conveyor belt." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The view is undeniably one of the best in the world, if you can see it over the selfie sticks." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Worst experience in Bangkok. Rude staff, insane prices, and you can't even enjoy the view because you're being pushed.
Go once for the Hangover photo, buy one drink, and leave. It's a bucket list item, not a hangout.

entries.embedding_text: Sky Bar at Lebua in Bangkok, Thailand. bar. tourist_trap. Made famous by 'The Hangover II', this rooftop bar is now a chaotic photo-op factory. Staff aggressively push overpriced champagne and herd guests like cattle. Red flags: Astronomical drink prices, Aggressive crowd control. Positives: Incredible skyline view.

entries.name: Jay Fai
entries.summary: The only street food vendor with a Michelin star, famous for her crab omelet. Yes, it is expensive for street food ($30+) and the wait is hours long, but the ingredients are premium quality and the cooking technique is legendary.

red_flags.evidence: "We waited 4 hours. You have to commit your whole day to this." (Food Blog)

positive_signals.evidence: "The crab omelet is a massive roll of pure, sweet crab meat held together by egg. Unmatched." (Michelin Guide)
"Watching Jay Fai herself cook every single dish in goggles is part of the magic." (Eater)

sample_reviews.text: Expensive for Bangkok but cheap for a Michelin meal. The crab is generous and fresh. Worth the hype.
It's good, but is it wait-4-hours good? I'm not sure. The price is shocking for a roadside stall.

entries.embedding_text: Jay Fai in Bangkok, Thailand. street_food. local_gem. The only street food vendor with a Michelin star, famous for her crab omelet. Expensive for street food ($30+) with long waits, but the premium ingredients and legendary technique justify it. Red flags: Extreme wait times. Positives: Michelin-star execution, One-woman show.

entries.name: Ichiran Shibuya
entries.summary: The 'McDonald's of Ramen'. While accessible for anxious tourists, the broth is factory-made and locals refuse to wait 45 minutes for a bowl they can get better/cheaper elsewhere.

red_flags.evidence: "No Tokyo local waits 45 mins for Ichiran when there are 5 better shops on the same block." (Reddit)
"It's the McDonald's of ramen. Consistent, but lacks soul." (Ramen Adventures)

positive_signals.evidence: "English menus, no speaking required, fully customizable. Great for anxiety-free dining." (Japan Guide)
"The spicy red sauce is addictive. It hits the spot every time." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Overrated. Broth is flat. You are queuing for the experience of sitting in a cubicle.
Best meal I had in Japan! The solo booth was so cool and I loved choosing my noodle firmness.

entries.embedding_text: Ichiran Shibuya in Tokyo, Japan. restaurant. tourist_trap. The 'McDonald's of Ramen'. Factory-made broth and locals refuse to wait 45 minutes for a bowl they can get better/cheaper elsewhere. Red flags: Locals won't wait, Mass-produced flavor. Positives: Tourist-friendly ordering, Consistently decent taste.

entries.name: Wangfujing Snack Street
entries.summary: A street famous for selling scorpions and starfish on sticks. This is purely theater for shock-value photos; locals never eat here. The food is often cold, stale, and exorbitantly priced compared to authentic Beijing hutong snacks.

red_flags.evidence: "Chinese people don't eat starfish. This is a show for foreigners." (The Beijinger)
"The dumplings were cold and hard. Just a rip-off." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Fun to walk through and see the scorpions moving, but don't buy anything." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Total trap. They yell at you to buy. The food looks plastic. Just take a photo and run.
I ate the scorpion on a dare. It tasted like burnt oil. 0/10 culinary experience, 10/10 story.

entries.embedding_text: Wangfujing Snack Street in Beijing, China. street_food. tourist_trap. Famous for selling scorpions and starfish on sticks. Purely theater for shock-value photos; locals never eat here. Food is cold, stale, and exorbitantly priced. Red flags: Fake 'exotic' food, Stale food at high prices. Positives: Visual spectacle.

entries.name: Opera Bar
entries.summary: The location is unbeatable, sitting directly between the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. While the drinks are pricey and it gets crowded, even locals admit the view is worth the 'tax'. The food has improved recently, moving it away from pure trap territory.

red_flags.evidence: "$14 for a schooner is steep, but you're paying rent on the harbour." (Broadsheet)
"Watch your chips. The seagulls are aggressive and will steal food from your hand." (Local Warning)

positive_signals.evidence: "Literally the best beer garden view on earth. Sunset here is non-negotiable." (Timeout Sydney)
"It's the first place I take anyone visiting Sydney. It's cliche but magic." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Food is average pub grub and expensive. Service is slow. But that view... I keep coming back.
Beware the seagulls! They swooped my burger. Drinks are nice though.

entries.embedding_text: Opera Bar in Sydney, Australia. bar. mixed. Unbeatable location between Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Pricey drinks, but locals admit view is worth the 'tax'. Food has improved. Red flags: Paying for the view, Seagull attacks. Positives: World-class views, Locals bring visitors here.

entries.name: Nusr-Et Steakhouse
entries.summary: Salt Bae's flagship is the definition of a viral tourist trap. Diners pay thousands for gold-covered steaks that critics describe as bland and chewy. It is theater for Instagram, with zero culinary merit to back up the mortgage-level bill.

red_flags.evidence: "$1000 for a tomahawk just because it's wrapped in cheap gold foil. The meat was overcooked." (Food Critic)
"You are paying for a guy in sunglasses to sprinkle salt. That's it." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "If he is there, it's a show. Everyone gets their phone out." (TimeOut Dubai)

sample_reviews.text: The biggest scam in Dubai. Service was arrogant, steak was cold, and the bill was insulting.
Fun experience but the food is average. You pay for the brand.

entries.embedding_text: Nusr-Et Steakhouse in Dubai, UAE. restaurant. tourist_trap. Salt Bae's flagship is the definition of a viral tourist trap. Diners pay thousands for bland, gold-covered steaks. Theater for Instagram with zero culinary merit. Red flags: Obscene prices for average meat, Performative dining. Positives: Celebrity sighting potential.

entries.name: Pujol
entries.summary: Consistently ranked in the World's Top 50, Pujol is famous for its 1000-day Mole Madre. While undeniably significant to Mexican gastronomy, some locals feel it has become sterile and catered entirely to foreign palates, lacking the punch of real Mexican food.

red_flags.evidence: "Flavors are muted... it feels like Mexican food explained to Europeans." (Local Food Blogger)
"You can eat better mole in Oaxaca for $5." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The Mole Madre is a profound history lesson on a plate. It deserves the accolades." (Chef's Table)
"Service is a ballet. Flawless execution." (Eater)

sample_reviews.text: It was an intellectual experience, not a soulful one. I respect it, but I didn't love it.
Best meal of my life. The mole is unlike anything I've ever tasted.

entries.embedding_text: Pujol in Mexico City, Mexico. restaurant. mixed. Consistently ranked in World's Top 50, famous for 1000-day Mole Madre. Undeniably significant, but some locals feel it's sterile and catered to foreign palates. Red flags: Caters to Western palates, Very expensive for CDMX. Positives: Culinary innovation, Impeccable service.

entries.name: El Moro
entries.summary: An institution since 1935 serving churros and hot chocolate 24/7. Despite having multiple locations now, the quality remains consistent and it is a beloved late-night ritual for Chilangos and tourists alike.

red_flags.evidence: "Expect a line at the Centro Historico location, but it moves fast." (Lonely Planet)

positive_signals.evidence: "My grandfather brought me here, I bring my kids. It's CDMX heritage." (Local Review)
"4 churros for cheap. The best snack in the city." (Google Maps)

sample_reviews.text: The Consuelo (ice cream sandwich) is life changing. A must visit.
Nothing beats dipping a fresh churro in Spanish chocolate at 2am. A classic.

entries.embedding_text: El Moro in Mexico City, Mexico. cafe. local_gem. Institution since 1935 serving churros and hot chocolate 24/7. Despite expansion, quality is consistent. Beloved late-night ritual for locals. Red flags: Lines at peak hours. Positives: Deeply ingrained in local culture, Very affordable.

entries.name: Mama Africa
entries.summary: A restaurant designed to give tourists a 'safari' dinner experience on Long Street. It serves game meat platters (crocodile, ostrich) accompanied by loud marimba bands. Locals rarely eat here; it's a caricature of African cuisine.

red_flags.evidence: "It's the Epcot version of Africa. Locals don't eat crocodile platters." (Cape Town Magazine)
"Meat was dry and tough. You pay for the band, not the food." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The band is energetic and fun if you want a party vibe." (TimeOut)

sample_reviews.text: Great music, terrible food. The crocodile tasted like chicken rubber. Tourist central.
Fun night out! We tried Kudu and Ostrich. A bit pricey but the band made it worth it.

entries.embedding_text: Mama Africa in Cape Town, South Africa. restaurant. tourist_trap. Designed to give tourists a 'safari' dinner experience. Serves game meat platters with loud marimba bands. Locals rarely eat here. Red flags: Stereotypical 'African' experience, Overpriced game meat. Positives: Live music atmosphere.

entries.name: La Vieja Rotiseria
entries.summary: Located in the Caminito (La Boca), this spot lures tourists with tango dancers on the sidewalk. The steak is notoriously bad (shoe-leather quality) and priced 3x higher than standard parrillas. It exploits the safety concerns of the area to keep tourists captive.

red_flags.evidence: "Worst parrillada in BA. Meat was grey and chewy." (Reddit)
"Dancers pull you in for a photo then demand money. Aggressive." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Good for people watching in the heart of La Boca." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: A total trap. They charge a 'cubierto' (sitting fee) and the meat is inedible. Go to Don Julio instead.
We stopped for a beer and to watch the Tango. Don't eat here, just drink.

entries.embedding_text: La Vieja Rotiseria in Buenos Aires, Argentina. restaurant. tourist_trap. Located in Caminito, lures tourists with tango dancers. Steak is notoriously bad and priced 3x higher than standard parrillas. Exploits safety concerns to trap tourists. Red flags: Terrible steak at premium prices, Aggressive street dancers. Positives: Right in the colorful Caminito.

entries.name: Xi'an Famous Foods
entries.summary: A local chain that started in a basement and conquered NYC. Known for hand-ripped cumin lamb noodles that are spicy, authentic, and incredibly cheap ($10-15). A staple for New Yorkers.

red_flags.evidence: "Don't expect service, just eat and go." (Infatuation)

positive_signals.evidence: "Impossible to beat the value for this flavor profile." (Serious Eats)
"I eat here once a week. It's the taste of Queens." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Spicy, oily, chewy noodles. Perfection. Not a fancy place but the food is 10/10.
Staff yelled out my number and the music was loud. Loved every second.

entries.embedding_text: Xi'an Famous Foods in New York, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Hand-ripped cumin lamb noodles that are spicy, authentic, and cheap. A staple for New Yorkers. Red flags: No frills/counter service only. Positives: Best cheap eat in NYC, Cult following.

entries.name: Joe's Pizza (Greenwich Village)
entries.summary: The quintessential NY slice shop. Despite the celebrity photos on the wall and the line out the door, the plain cheese slice remains the gold standard: thin, crispy, and consistent. Locals and tourists unite here.

red_flags.evidence: "Line moves fast but it's always there." (Eater)

positive_signals.evidence: "The definition of a NY slice. No gimmicks." (Barstool Sports)
"Still tastes like it did in the 90s." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Spiderman worked here for a reason. Best slice in the city.
Touristy? Yes. Worth it? Absolutely. It's just good pizza.

entries.embedding_text: Joe's Pizza (Greenwich Village) in New York, USA. street_food. local_gem. The quintessential NY slice shop. Despite celebrity fame, the plain cheese slice remains the gold standard. Red flags: Always a line. Positives: The benchmark slice, Unchanged for decades.

entries.name: Fuunji
entries.summary: Legendary Tsukemen (dipping ramen) shop in Shinjuku. There is always a line of locals and savvy tourists, but the efficiency is incredible and the rich, fishy broth is world-class.

red_flags.evidence: "You stand behind the people eating while you wait. High pressure." (Ramen Beast)

positive_signals.evidence: "The umami bomb of the soup is unforgettable." (Tablelog)
"Full of locals on their lunch break." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Worth the wait. The chef moves like a machine. Delicious.
Intense atmosphere. You eat fast and leave. But the noodles are perfect.

entries.embedding_text: Fuunji in Tokyo, Japan. restaurant. local_gem. Legendary Tsukemen (dipping ramen) shop in Shinjuku. Always a line of locals. Incredible efficiency and rich broth. Red flags: Cramped standing/waiting. Positives: Top-tier Tsukemen, Salaryman favorite.

entries.name: Sushi Dai
entries.summary: Located in Toyosu Market. Famous for 3+ hour waits. While some call the wait a trap, the Omakase is universally rated as high-end quality for a mid-range price. A 'Time Trap' but a 'Food Gem'.

red_flags.evidence: "We waited 4.5 hours. It breaks your soul." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "For the price, the fish quality is unbeatable." (The Tokyo Chapter)
"Chefs are chatty and welcoming, unlike many serious sushi spots." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: The sushi melted in my mouth. But honestly, no food is worth a 5 hour wait.
Best sushi breakfast of my life. Go at 4am.

entries.embedding_text: Sushi Dai in Tokyo, Japan. restaurant. local_gem. Located in Toyosu Market. Famous for 3+ hour waits. While the wait is brutal, the Omakase is high-end quality for a mid-range price. Red flags: Insane wait times. Positives: Incredible value for Omakase, Friendly chefs.

entries.name: Wattana Panich
entries.summary: Famous for the 'perpetual stew' that has been boiling for 40+ years. The massive cauldron of beef broth sits curbside. It attracts tourists, but the depth of flavor keeps it firmly in the 'Gem' category for locals.

red_flags.description: Visuals of old soup scare some
red_flags.evidence: "The ring of fat on the pot is decades old. Not for the squeamish." (Food Blog)

positive_signals.evidence: "You cannot fake 40 years of reduction. The broth is medicinal." (Mark Wiens)
"Seeing the massive pot is an attraction in itself." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Rich, herbal, beefy. The goat stew is also amazing.
Looked scary but tasted heavenly. Cheap and fast.

entries.embedding_text: Wattana Panich in Bangkok, Thailand. street_food. local_gem. Famous for the 'perpetual stew' boiling for 40+ years. Massive cauldron sits curbside. Depth of flavor keeps it a local favorite. Red flags: Visuals of old soup scare some. Positives: Unique flavor depth, The giant cauldron.

entries.name: Moulin Rouge
entries.summary: The world's most famous cabaret is a cramped, mass-produced assembly line. You are packed onto tables with strangers, served cheap champagne, and the show—while technically impressive—feels dated and soulless.

red_flags.evidence: "You are touching elbows with strangers. No personal space." (TripAdvisor)
"€150 for a show and cheap sparkling wine." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "It is THE Moulin Rouge. You go for the name." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Strictly for tourists. Parisians wouldn't be caught dead here. The dancers look bored.
I loved the costumes! Yes it's crowded, but it's a classic.

entries.embedding_text: Moulin Rouge in Paris, France. attraction. tourist_trap. World's most famous cabaret is a cramped, mass-produced assembly line. Packed tables, cheap champagne, and a dated show. Red flags: Packed like sardines, Overpriced ticket/drinks. Positives: Bucket list item.

entries.name: Empire State Building
entries.summary: Iconic, but the experience is a nightmare of lines, airport-style security, and fences blocking the view. Savvy visitors know to go to 'Top of the Rock' or 'Summit' instead—where you can actually *see* the Empire State Building.

red_flags.evidence: "You wait in line for the elevator, then line for security, then line for the view." (Google Maps)
"Go to Top of the Rock. You can't see the ESB if you are standing on it." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "King Kong climbed it. It's history." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Skip it. Go to Summit One Vanderbilt. Better view, less cage.
It's a classic. I cried when I saw the view.

entries.embedding_text: Empire State Building in New York, USA. attraction. tourist_trap. Iconic, but a nightmare of lines and security fences. Savvy visitors go to Top of the Rock to actually see the ESB. Red flags: Lines and security, Better views exist elsewhere. Positives: Most famous building in NYC.

entries.name: Tokyo Skytree
entries.summary: The tallest tower in Japan offers good views, but it is expensive and crowded. Locals prefer the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building (which is free) or Shibuya Sky (which is open-air).

red_flags.evidence: "Why pay ¥3000 when the Metro Gov building is free?" (Japan Guide)
"Spent more time in line than looking at the view." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "You can see Mt Fuji on a clear day. Unmatched height." (Tablelog)

sample_reviews.text: Go to Shibuya Sky instead. This is just a glass box high up.
The mall at the bottom is fun (Pokemon Center!), view was nice.

entries.embedding_text: Tokyo Skytree in Tokyo, Japan. attraction. mixed. Tallest tower in Japan. Good views but expensive and crowded. Locals prefer free alternatives or open-air decks. Red flags: Expensive vs Free alternatives, Crowds and elevator waits. Positives: Highest point in Tokyo.

entries.name: Gondola Rides
entries.summary: The ultimate Venice cliché. It costs €80-100 for 30 minutes. It is undeniably expensive and touristy, but the city fixes the price (so no scams if you know the rate) and seeing Venice from the water is arguably essential.

red_flags.evidence: "It felt like 15 minutes. Very rushed." (TripAdvisor)
"You are bumper to bumper with other tourists. Not romantic." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "You can't do this anywhere else. It's magic despite the price." (Travel Blog)
"Part of the history of the city." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Rip off. Just take the Vaporetto (water bus).
Yes it's expensive, but my wife loved it. The gondolier was singing. Classic.

entries.embedding_text: Gondola Rides in Venice, Italy. attraction. mixed. The ultimate Venice cliché. €80+ for 30 minutes. Undeniably expensive and touristy, but seeing Venice from the water is unique. Red flags: Very short for the price, Canal traffic jams. Positives: Unique to Venice, Traditional transport.

entries.name: The Little Mermaid Statue
entries.summary: Infamously underwhelming. A tiny statue in an industrial harbor, surrounded by busloads of tourists fighting for a photo. Danes joke that it is the most disappointing landmark in Europe.

red_flags.evidence: "It's tiny and sitting in front of a factory." (Reddit)
"You risk falling in the water just to see it." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "It is the symbol of Copenhagen." (Guidebook)

sample_reviews.text: Walked 30 mins for a rock with a small lady on it. Disappointing.
As a Dane, I never go here. We send tourists here so they leave us alone in the good spots.

entries.embedding_text: The Little Mermaid Statue in Copenhagen, Denmark. attraction. tourist_trap. Infamously underwhelming. A tiny statue in an industrial harbor surrounded by tourists. Danes joke it is the most disappointing landmark. Red flags: Underwhelming size/location, Crowd crushing. Positives: City symbol.

entries.name: Madame Tussauds London
entries.summary: The definition of a global tourist trap. Expensive tickets (£35+) for a crowded walkthrough of wax figures that often look nothing like the celebrities. Locals actively avoid this area.

red_flags.evidence: "Over £100 for a family to see motionless dolls... absolute robbery." (TripAdvisor)
"You are shuffled through like cattle, barely time for a photo." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "My 10-year-old loved the Marvel 4D experience." (Mumsnet)

sample_reviews.text: Complete waste of money. Spend your time at the free museums in London instead.
It was busy but fun to take selfies with the Royal Family figures.

entries.embedding_text: Madame Tussauds London in London, UK. attraction. tourist_trap. Expensive tickets (£35+) for a crowded walkthrough of wax figures. Locals avoid. Red flags: Exorbitant price for wax dolls, Overcrowded conveyor belt. Positives: Good for young children.

entries.name: Hard Rock Cafe Times Square
entries.summary: Generic, overpriced burgers served in a loud, corporate environment. You pay a premium for the location and the memorabilia on the walls, with food quality comparable to a fast-food chain.

red_flags.evidence: "Eating here in NYC is like going to Italy and eating Pizza Hut." (Eater NY)
"$22 for a burger that tastes like it was frozen 6 months ago." (Yelp)

positive_signals.evidence: "Cool to see the Beatles' suits, even if the food was bad." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Please, I beg you, walk two blocks to a real restaurant. This is a factory.
Great atmosphere and loud music! The service was slow but we expected that.

entries.embedding_text: Hard Rock Cafe Times Square in New York, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Generic, overpriced burgers in a corporate environment. You pay for location and memorabilia. Red flags: Zero local connection, Mediocre food at premium prices. Positives: Music memorabilia.

entries.name: Checkpoint Charlie
entries.summary: Historically significant location reduced to a tacky photo-op. The booth is a replica, and until recently, actors dressed as soldiers would aggressively demand money for photos. It's surrounded by cheap souvenir shops selling fake gas masks.

red_flags.evidence: "The actors were banned for harassing tourists for cash, but the vibe remains scams-y." (Berlin News)
"It's a small shed in the middle of a street... underwhelming and fake." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The outdoor display boards and the nearby Haus am Checkpoint Charlie museum are actually educational." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Just a hut in the road. Go to the Berlin Wall Memorial instead for real history.
Crowded but you have to see it once if you are in Berlin.

entries.embedding_text: Checkpoint Charlie in Berlin, Germany. attraction. tourist_trap. Historically significant location reduced to a tacky photo-op with a replica booth. Surrounded by souvenir shops. Red flags: Disneyfication of history, Aggressive touts. Positives: Museum nearby is good.

entries.name: Manneken Pis
entries.summary: A tiny (61cm) statue of a peeing boy that draws massive crowds of tourists. It is notoriously difficult to see through the wall of selfie sticks, and visitors are almost universally disappointed by its size.

red_flags.evidence: "It is shockingly small. You fight through 500 people to see a garden gnome." (Reddit)
"Watch your wallet. The crowd is a playground for thieves." (Local Police Warning)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's fun when they dress him up in different outfits." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Walked past it without realizing. It's tiny. Go for the waffles nearby, not the statue.
The ultimate Brussels prank on tourists. We locals laugh at the crowds.

entries.embedding_text: Manneken Pis in Brussels, Belgium. attraction. tourist_trap. Tiny (61cm) statue of a peeing boy. Draws massive crowds, notoriously difficult to see, and underwhelming. Red flags: Underwhelming and crowded, Pickpocket hotspot. Positives: Funny costumes.

entries.name: Hofbräuhaus München
entries.summary: The world's most famous beer hall. It is loud, chaotic, and dominated by tourists, but the beer is fresh, the history is genuine (founded 1589), and the live Oompah music delivers the expected Bavarian atmosphere.

red_flags.evidence: "Waiters are rude and you have to fight for a table." (TripAdvisor)
"The pork knuckle was dry. You come here for beer, not the food." (Food Blog)

positive_signals.evidence: "Despite the tourists, the painted ceilings and brass band are the real deal." (Rick Steves)
"1 liter of beer is standard Munich price, not a rip-off." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: It's a tourist trap but a fun one. Drink the beer, listen to the band, eat somewhere else.
Noisy, rude staff, and food was cold. Augustiner Keller is much better.

entries.embedding_text: Hofbräuhaus München in Munich, Germany. restaurant. mixed. World's most famous beer hall. Loud, chaotic, dominated by tourists. Beer is fresh and history is genuine, but food is average. Red flags: Aggressive service, Average canteen food. Positives: Historic atmosphere, Fair beer prices.

entries.name: Tim Ho Wan (Sham Shui Po)
entries.summary: Famous as the 'cheapest Michelin-starred restaurant in the world'. While they have expanded globally, the original locations in HK still serve incredible BBQ pork buns for a few dollars. It's crowded, but the quality-to-price ratio is undeniable.

red_flags.evidence: "They want you to eat and leave. Tables are shared." (OpenRice)

positive_signals.evidence: "The baked BBQ pork buns are a masterpiece of texture and flavor." (Michelin Guide)
"Michelin quality for the price of a McDonald's meal." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: The queue moves fast. The pork buns are life changing. Don't expect luxury, expect flavor.
Standard quality compared to other HK dim sum places, but the price is good.

entries.embedding_text: Tim Ho Wan (Sham Shui Po) in Hong Kong. restaurant. local_gem. Cheapest Michelin-starred restaurant in the world. Incredible BBQ pork buns for a few dollars. Crowded but high quality-to-price ratio. Red flags: Rushed service. Positives: World-class Dim Sum, Incredibly cheap.

entries.name: Hawker Chan (Chinatown Complex)
entries.summary: The original stall that won a Michelin star (and later lost it). Locals are divided; some respect the legacy, while many argue the quality dropped after expansion and that there are better soy sauce chicken stalls in the same hawker center.

red_flags.evidence: "Since franchising, the chicken is often dry and the sauce less complex." (DaniFoodings)
"Tourists queue here; locals go to Emerald Soy Sauce Chicken two rows down." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "For $3-5 SGD, it is still a very good meal." (SethLui.com)
"Portions were more generous than I expected, considering the affordable prices." (Burpple)

sample_reviews.text: It's good, but not mind-blowing. The star was for the price, not because it's the best chicken in SG.
Worth the wait to try the famous chicken. Skin was crispy and sauce was sweet.

entries.embedding_text: Hawker Chan (Chinatown Complex) in Singapore. street_food. mixed. Original stall that won a Michelin star. Locals divided, arguing quality dropped after expansion and better options exist nearby. Red flags: Mass expansion issues, Better options nearby. Positives: Still very affordable, Good portion sizes.

entries.name: Pastéis de Belém
entries.summary: The birthplace of the pastel de nata. Despite the constant line of tourists, this is a legitimate institution. The tarts are served warm, the recipe is secret, and they are distinctively different (and often considered better) than competitors.

red_flags.evidence: "The line looks terrifying, but it moves very fast." (Lonely Planet)

positive_signals.evidence: "Crispier crust and creamier filling than any other nata in Lisbon." (Serious Eats)
"Even locals admit these are the gold standard, though we usually buy them to-go." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: I thought it was hype, but they really are different. The pastry is salty and crispy. Incredible.
Don't queue for a table, just go to the 'take away' counter inside. Best with cinnamon.

entries.embedding_text: Pastéis de Belém in Lisbon, Portugal. cafe. local_gem. Birthplace of the pastel de nata. Despite tourist crowds, the tarts are served warm and considered the gold standard. Red flags: Always crowded. Positives: Unique recipe, Locals respect it.

entries.name: Mercado de San Miguel
entries.summary: A stunning iron-glass market that has transformed into a high-end tapas food court. The food is high quality, but the prices are double the city average and the clientele is 100% tourists. It's a 'Gourmet Trap'.

red_flags.evidence: "€15 for a gin tonic and €4 for a single oyster is not normal Madrid pricing." (Madrid Food Tour)
"Locals don't buy groceries here anymore, it's strictly for visitors." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Everything is delicious and looks beautiful, even if you overpay." (The Infatuation)
"A feast for the eyes." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Go for photos and maybe one drink, then go to La Latina for real tapas.
Expensive but convenient to try many things in one place.

entries.embedding_text: Mercado de San Miguel in Madrid, Spain. market. mixed. Stunning iron-glass market turned high-end tapas food court. High quality food but prices are double the average and 100% tourists. Red flags: Inflated prices, No locals shop here. Positives: High quality variety, Beautiful architecture.

entries.name: Pat's King of Steaks
entries.summary: The inventor of the cheesesteak, famous for its rivalry with Geno's across the street. While historic, the steak is often described as gristly and unseasoned compared to local favorites like Dalessandro's or John's Roast Pork.

red_flags.evidence: "Meat was chopped too coarse and was dry. Purely running on fame." (Philly Eater)
"No one from Philly eats at Pat's or Geno's. Those are for tourists." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "You have to respect the history of where it started." (Bon Appetit)

sample_reviews.text: Tourist hype. Go to Dalessandro's or Ishkabibble's.
I loved the 'Whiz Wit' experience! The line was fun.

entries.embedding_text: Pat's King of Steaks in Philadelphia, USA. street_food. tourist_trap. Inventor of the cheesesteak. Historic, but steak is often gristly and unseasoned compared to local favorites. Red flags: Resting on laurels, Locals go elsewhere. Positives: The original.

entries.name: teamLab Planets
entries.summary: An immersive digital art museum where you walk barefoot through water and crystal lights. While it is incredibly popular on Instagram, the sensory experience is genuinely unique and technically impressive, earning praise from art lovers and selfie-seekers alike.

red_flags.evidence: "Packed with influencers blocking the path for photos." (Japan Guide)

positive_signals.evidence: "Walking through the knee-deep water projection is unlike anything else." (TimeOut Tokyo)
"Despite crowds, the flow is managed perfectly." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: I thought it would be a gimmick, but it was actually magical. The flower room is stunning.
A bit smelly in the locker room (feet), but the art is cool.

entries.embedding_text: teamLab Planets in Tokyo, Japan. attraction. local_gem. Immersive digital art museum. Incredibly popular on Instagram, but the sensory experience (barefoot, water) is genuinely unique and technically impressive. Red flags: High tourist density. Positives: Unique sensory experience, Well organized.

entries.name: Señor Frog's
entries.summary: The epitome of the spring break tourist trap. Overpriced, sugary drinks served in yard glasses, balloon hats, and conga lines. The food is afterthought Tex-Mex, and the entire business model is based on getting tourists drunk enough to ignore the bill.

red_flags.evidence: "$20 for a margarita made with cheap mix and barely any tequila." (TripAdvisor)
"You could be in Vegas or Florida. Nothing Mexican about it." (Travel Blog)

positive_signals.evidence: "If you want to get wasted and dance on tables, this is the place." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Fun for 20 minutes until you see the bill. Hidden service charges everywhere.
Avoid. Go to downtown Cancun (Parque de las Palapas) for real food.

entries.embedding_text: Señor Frog's in Cancun, Mexico. bar. tourist_trap. Epitome of spring break trap. Overpriced sugary drinks, balloon hats, and conga lines. Food is afterthought Tex-Mex. Red flags: Expensive bad drinks, Artificial atmosphere. Positives: Party vibe.

entries.name: Franklin Barbecue
entries.summary: Famous for 4-hour lines that start at 7 AM. While it attracts tourists worldwide, it is NOT a trap. The brisket is widely considered the best in the known universe, and the 'line culture' is a social event with free beer and chairs.

red_flags.evidence: "You have to commit half a day to lunch." (Eater Austin)
"Sold out by 1pm. Get there early or don't bother." (Yelp)

positive_signals.evidence: "The fat renders into something like meat candy. It lives up to the hype." (Texas Monthly)
"The line is a tailgate party. Everyone is happy." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: I hate lines. I hate hype. But I ate this brisket and I understood everything.
Sold out by 1pm. Get there early or don't bother.

entries.embedding_text: Franklin Barbecue in Austin, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Famous for 4-hour lines. Not a trap; brisket is considered best in the world. Line culture is a social event. Red flags: The Wait, Frequently sold out. Positives: Best brisket globally, Fun waiting experience.

entries.name: Schwartz's Deli
entries.summary: The oldest deli in Canada, serving Montreal Smoked Meat. It is cramped, cash-only, and always has a line, but the product (cured for 10 days, hand-sliced) is unique to the city and superior to tourist-focused competitors.

red_flags.evidence: "You are elbow-to-elbow with strangers. Not for claustrophobes." (TripAdvisor)
"Bring cash or use their ATM with high fees." (Google Maps)

positive_signals.evidence: "The medium-fat sandwich melts in your mouth. Unmatched." (Montreal Eater)
"No menu changes, no renovations. Pure history." (Globe and Mail)

sample_reviews.text: Get the cherry coke and a medium fat sandwich. Don't ask for a menu. Best in the world.
The line is annoying but you can buy the meat at the takeout door next to it.

entries.embedding_text: Schwartz's Deli in Montreal, Canada. restaurant. local_gem. Oldest deli in Canada. Cramped, cash-only, always a line. Smoked meat (cured 10 days) is unique and superior to competitors. Red flags: Cramped communal seating, Cash only. Positives: Iconic meat quality, Unchanged since 1928.

entries.name: Café Sacher (Hotel Sacher)
entries.summary: Home of the world's most famous chocolate cake. The setting is opulent and historic, but many visitors (and food critics) find the cake itself dry and overrated compared to the moister version at Café Demel.

red_flags.evidence: "The cake is notoriously dry. You are paying for the brand, not the taste." (Serious Eats)
"Waited 45 mins in the cold for a slice of cake." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "It is the original. The interior is stunningly Viennese." (Lonely Planet)
"Feels like stepping back into the empire." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Go to Demel instead. Sacher is dry and touristy. Demel is where the locals go.
It's a bucket list item. The coffee was great, the cake was... okay.

entries.embedding_text: Café Sacher in Vienna, Austria. cafe. mixed. Home of famous Sacher Torte. Opulent and historic setting, but cake is often considered dry and overrated compared to Café Demel. Red flags: Dry cake, Queues. Positives: The original location, Elegant atmosphere.

entries.name: Pike Place Chowder
entries.summary: A rare spot that is both a massive tourist trap (lines wrapping around the block) AND a culinary award winner. The chowder is legitimately Hall-of-Fame level, but locals often avoid it due to the crowds, opting to order ahead or go to their second location.

red_flags.evidence: "Line is 45 minutes minimum on a weekend." (Seattle Times)
"Small shop... crowded... limited seating." (HappyCow)

positive_signals.evidence: "The clam chowder has won more awards than any other in the nation." (Food Network)
"Creamy, loaded with clams, perfect sourdough bowl." (Yelp)

sample_reviews.text: Pro tip: Order online for pickup and skip the line. Chowder is legit.
Good chowder but not worth waiting an hour in the rain.

entries.embedding_text: Pike Place Chowder in Seattle, USA. restaurant. mixed. Massive tourist trap with long lines, but the chowder is legitimately Hall-of-Fame level. Locals order ahead or go to second location. Red flags: Insane lines, Limited seating. Positives: Award winning food, Consistent quality.

entries.name: Anne Frank House
entries.summary: A profoundly moving historical site. While getting tickets is stressful (they sell out weeks in advance), the museum itself is respectful, well-curated, and absolutely essential. It resists commercialization inside.

red_flags.evidence: "If you don't book 6 weeks out, you aren't getting in." (Rick Steves)
"Old part of the museum and Secret Annex are not accessible... stairs are very steep." (Official Site)

positive_signals.evidence: "The empty rooms speak louder than any exhibit. A deeply emotional experience." (Guardian)
"Banning photos keeps the atmosphere solemn and respectful." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: It's not a 'fun' attraction, but it's the most important thing to do in Amsterdam.
The ticket system is a nightmare, but once you are in, it is powerful.

entries.embedding_text: Anne Frank House in Amsterdam, Netherlands. attraction. local_gem. Profoundly moving historical site. Tickets sell out weeks in advance, but the museum is respectful, well-curated, and essential. Red flags: Impossible ticketing, Not wheelchair accessible. Positives: Respectful and authentic, No photo policy.

entries.name: La Sagrada Familia
entries.summary: Gaudi's unfinished masterpiece is the most visited site in Spain, yet it defies the 'trap' label due to its sheer architectural brilliance. The interior light show is spiritual, and the audio guide is excellent.

red_flags.evidence: "Always packed. Book the earliest slot to breathe." (Lonely Planet)
"Views from the towers are not particularly remarkable... not worth extra cost." (Rick Steves Forum)

positive_signals.evidence: "There is nothing else like it on earth. The stained glass effect is blindingly beautiful." (Architecture Digest)
"Your ticket literally pays for the building to be finished." (Official Site)

sample_reviews.text: I thought I'd hate it because of the crowds. I cried. It's spectacular.
Skip the towers (claustrophobic and not worth extra cost), but the basilica is a must.

entries.embedding_text: La Sagrada Familia in Barcelona, Spain. attraction. local_gem. Gaudi's unfinished masterpiece. Defies 'trap' label due to sheer architectural brilliance. Interior light show is spiritual. Red flags: Crowds, Towers are skippable. Positives: Architectural wonder, Ticket funds construction.

entries.name: Tsukiji Outer Market
entries.summary: The famous wholesale auction moved to Toyosu, but the 'Outer Market' remains. It is now 100% focused on tourists with overpriced Wagyu skewers and strawberry mochi. However, the sushi quality in the sit-down restaurants remains very high.

red_flags.evidence: "¥4000 for a crab leg is robbery. They prey on confusion." (Tokyo Cheapo)
"You can't walk. It's a crush of bodies." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The sushi restaurants tucked away in alleys still get the best catch." (Sushi Blog)

sample_reviews.text: It's a theme park now. Go to Ameyoko market for cheaper street food.
Expensive but the Tamagoyaki (egg omelet) on a stick was delicious.

entries.embedding_text: Tsukiji Outer Market in Tokyo, Japan. market. mixed. Wholesale market moved, leaving a tourist-focused zone. Overpriced street food (Wagyu skewers). Sushi quality in sit-down restaurants remains high. Red flags: Street food markup, Overcrowded. Positives: Fresh fish availability.

entries.name: Café Tortoni
entries.summary: The oldest cafe in Argentina (1858). While it has a line of tourists down the block and mediocre churros, the interior remains a stunning example of Belle Époque architecture and a cultural landmark.

red_flags.evidence: "Waited an hour. The churros were cold." (TripAdvisor)
"Coffee is burnt. You are there for the photos." (Local Guide)

positive_signals.evidence: "The stained glass and marble tables are breathtaking." (Architectural Digest)

sample_reviews.text: Skip the line, go to Las Violetas instead. Better food, same vibe.
Beautiful place to sit and imagine Borges writing. Service was old school.

entries.embedding_text: Café Tortoni in Buenos Aires, Argentina. cafe. mixed. Oldest cafe in Argentina (1858). Long tourist lines and mediocre food, but the Belle Époque interior is stunning and culturally significant. Red flags: Long queues, Food is secondary. Positives: Historic interior.

entries.name: Tacos El Califa de León
entries.summary: Recently awarded a Michelin star, this tiny stand has only four items on the menu (steak tacos). There is no seating, the meat quality is exceptional, and despite the new fame, it remains a gritty, authentic experience.

red_flags.evidence: "You eat standing up next to a hot grill. It's intense." (Eater)
"$5 USD per taco... absolutely ridiculous prices for a stand." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: " The Gaonera taco is so tender you don't even need teeth." (Michelin Guide)
"No sides, no drinks, just meat and tortillas made fresh." (Culinary Backstreets)

sample_reviews.text: Simple perfection. The red sauce is spicy! Don't be scared by the neighborhood.
Pricey for a taco ($5 USD) but the quality is undeniable.

entries.embedding_text: Tacos El Califa de León in Mexico City, Mexico. street_food. local_gem. Michelin-starred tiny stand with only four items. No seating, exceptional meat quality. Gritty, authentic experience. Red flags: No seating/amenities, Expensive for street food. Positives: Michelin quality meat, Pure focus on product.

entries.name: Ben's Chili Bowl
entries.summary: A civil rights landmark on U Street famous for its Half-Smoke. While culturally essential to DC history, many locals admit the food is greasy and heavy, and better chili exists elsewhere. You go for the history, not the gastronomy.

red_flags.evidence: "The chili is mostly grease and salt. It's nostalgia food." (Washington Post comment)

positive_signals.evidence: "It survived the riots. It fed MLK. It's holy ground." (Eater DC)
"At 2am, nothing beats a half-smoke." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Bill Cosby is off the wall, but Obama is on it. Food is mediocre, vibe is 10/10.
Classic DC experience. The half-smoke was spicy and messy.

entries.embedding_text: Ben's Chili Bowl in Washington DC, USA. restaurant. mixed. Civil rights landmark famous for Half-Smoke. Culturally essential, but food is greasy and heavy. You go for history, not gastronomy. Red flags: Greasy/Average food. Positives: Black history landmark, Late night staple.

entries.name: Voodoo Doughnut
entries.summary: Famous for long lines, pink boxes, and donuts topped with cereal or bacon. It is the definition of an 'Instagram Trap'. Locals almost universally prefer Blue Star or Pip's, citing Voodoo's stale dough and reliance on shock value toppings.

red_flags.evidence: "Friends don't let friends eat Voodoo. Go to Blue Star." (Reddit)
"Donuts were dry, clearly made hours ago. Just sugar overload." (Willamette Week)

positive_signals.evidence: "The voodoo doll donut is cute for a photo." (TripAdvisor)
"Tons of vegan options and everything is always delicious." (HappyCow)

sample_reviews.text: Waited 45 mins for a stale donut with Fruit Loops on it. Never again.
It's a Portland rite of passage. Just go once for the weirdness.

entries.embedding_text: Voodoo Doughnut in Portland, USA. cafe. tourist_trap. Famous for pink boxes and cereal toppings. 'Instagram Trap'. Locals prefer Blue Star, citing stale dough and reliance on shock value. Red flags: Locals hate it, Stale/Dry product. Positives: Fun branding, Extensive vegan menu.

entries.name: Lau Pa Sat (Satay Street)
entries.summary: A historic Victorian structure in the financial district. At night, the street closes for 'Satay Street'. It is undeniably atmospheric and the satay is tasty, but prices are 20-30% higher than neighborhood hawker centers and aggressive touts can be annoying.

red_flags.evidence: "You pay for the location. East Coast Lagoon has cheaper/better satay." (Honeycombers)
"Stall owners will push 'sets' on you that cost more than individual sticks." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Eating satay on the street surrounded by skyscrapers is a vibe." (TimeOut Singapore)
"The satay is consistently good, charred and smoky." (LadyIronChef)
