sample_reviews.text: Great atmosphere but watch out for the 'set menu' upsell. Just order sticks.
A bit pricey for hawker food, but clean and beautiful.

entries.embedding_text: Lau Pa Sat in Singapore. market. mixed. Historic structure, famous for Satay Street at night. Atmospheric and tasty, but prices are higher than neighborhood centers and touts are aggressive. Red flags: Tourist pricing, Aggressive selling. Positives: Unique atmosphere, Reliable food.

entries.name: The Venetian Gondolas
entries.summary: A motorized boat ride through an indoor shopping mall with a painted sky. The gondoliers sing (often beautifully), but the experience is short, expensive ($39/person), and entirely artificial.

red_flags.evidence: "It's a boat in a chlorinated pool inside a mall. Tacky." (Reddit)
"Ride lasted 12 minutes. Almost $40 per person. Do the math." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Cheesy but my girlfriend loved the singing." (Yelp)

sample_reviews.text: Overpriced mall ride. You are being watched by shoppers eating gelato.
The singer was actually talented. Good for a laugh.

entries.embedding_text: The Venetian Gondolas in Las Vegas, USA. attraction. tourist_trap. Motorized boat ride through an indoor mall. Gondoliers sing, but experience is short, expensive ($39/person), and artificial. Red flags: Fake Venice, Short duration. Positives: Romantic cliche.

entries.name: Gwangjang Market
entries.summary: Made globally famous by Netflix, this market is a battleground between authentic deliciousness and tourist exploitation. While the mung bean pancakes remain legendary, specific stalls (especially the 'Netflix lady' knife noodles) have been caught overcharging tourists and serving smaller portions.

red_flags.evidence: "Vendors were caught serving smaller portions to foreigners for the same price. It was a national scandal." (Korea JoongAng Daily)
"You cannot move. You eat with strangers' elbows in your ribs." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The crispy bindaetteok at Sun-hui's stall is still the best in the city." (Seoul Eats)
"Despite the crowds, the energy of steaming pots and shouting ajummas is infectious." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: The knife noodle lady was rude and the portion was tiny. Go to the stalls on the side streets instead.
Yes it's touristy, but the raw beef bibimbap is life changing. Just avoid the main intersection.

entries.embedding_text: Gwangjang Market in Seoul, South Korea. market. mixed. Netflix fame brought crowds and some overcharging scandals (knife noodles). However, Mung Bean Pancakes and Raw Beef remain authentic and high quality. Red flags: Tourist surcharges, Extreme overcrowding. Positives: Bindaetteok is elite, Vibrant energy.

entries.name: Myeongdong Street Food Alley
entries.summary: A dedicated tourist zone selling 'Korean' street food that locals never eat (lobster tails, rainbow cheese). Prices are 2-3x higher than other districts, and the flavors are standardized for international palates.

red_flags.description: Double the price of normal markets
red_flags.evidence: "₩15,000 for a lobster tail that is mostly shell. Pure robbery." (Reddit)
"Locals do not eat rainbow cheese toast. This is theme park food." (Seoulistic)

positive_signals.evidence: "If you are intimidated by local markets, this is an easy, safe entry point." (Travel Blog)
"You can try 20 different things in a 500m walk." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Fun to look at, but don't eat here. Go to Namdaemun for real food at half the price.
Expensive but the egg bread was tasty and hot.

entries.embedding_text: Myeongdong Street Food Alley in Seoul, South Korea. street_food. tourist_trap. Designated tourist zone selling expensive, Instagram-focused food (lobster, rainbow cheese). Locals avoid. Prices are 2-3x higher than average. Red flags: Double the price, Food made for Instagram. Positives: Convenient and English-friendly, Huge selection.

entries.name: Khaosan Road Street Food
entries.summary: The backpacking center of the universe. The Pad Thai sold from carts here is famously ketchup-sweet, pre-cooked, and inferior to literally any other street corner in Bangkok. It serves one purpose: soaking up cheap alcohol.

red_flags.evidence: "It's orange, sweet, and mushy. Designed for drunk palates only." (Eating Thai Food)
"They charge you 100 Baht just to take a photo of the scorpions." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "You don't go for the food, you go for the chaos and meeting people." (Nomadic Matt)
"Buckets of cocktail for $5. Cannot beat the price to get wasted." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: The Pad Thai tasted like ketchup noodles. Avoid the carts here.
I ate a scorpion and drank a bucket. 10/10 night, 0/10 food.

entries.embedding_text: Khaosan Road Street Food in Bangkok, Thailand. street_food. tourist_trap. Backpacking center. Pad Thai is ketchup-sweet and pre-cooked. Scorpions are props for photos. Red flags: Worst Pad Thai in Thailand, Scorpion sellers. Positives: Legendary party vibe, Dirt cheap alcohol.

entries.name: Nishiki Market
entries.summary: Once 'Kyoto's Kitchen', it is now a congested tunnel of tourists eating food on sticks. Traditional pickle shops are being replaced by souvenir stands. Locals generally avoid it due to the 'tourist pollution' and difficulty walking.

red_flags.evidence: "Grandmothers can't do their shopping here anymore because of the wall of tourists." (Japan Times)
"You get yelled at for walking with food, but there is nowhere to stand." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Aritsugu knives are still world-class if you can reach the counter." (Kyoto Foodie)
"The colors and variety of seafood are great for photos." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: It's just a crush of people. We couldn't stop to look at anything.
Go at 9am when it opens. The soy milk donuts are still worth it.

entries.embedding_text: Nishiki Market in Kyoto, Japan. market. tourist_trap. Formerly 'Kyoto's Kitchen', now a congested tourist tunnel. Locals avoid due to crowds. Traditional shops replaced by souvenirs. Red flags: Locals pushed out, No eating while walking rule. Positives: Some historic shops remain, Visual spectacle.

entries.name: Hanoi Train Street
entries.summary: A narrow residential street where cafes operate illegally on active train tracks. It is dangerous, frequently closed by police, and cafe owners aggressively force tourists to buy drinks to 'allow' them to stand there.

red_flags.evidence: "A lady blocked the public road and said 'No coffee no photo'." (TripAdvisor)
"Police barricade the entrances randomly. You might travel there for nothing." (Vietnam Coracle)

positive_signals.evidence: "Feeling the train brush past your nose is a genuine adrenaline rush." (Travel Blog)
"It is undeniably the best photo you will take in Hanoi." (Instagram)

sample_reviews.text: Dangerous and stressful. Cafe owners are aggressive. Not worth the risk.
We got lucky and saw the train. Scariest and coolest thing ever.

entries.embedding_text: Hanoi Train Street in Hanoi, Vietnam. attraction. tourist_trap. Narrow street with illegal cafes on active train tracks. Dangerous, often closed by police, and owners force drink purchases. Red flags: Forced cafe purchases, Unpredictable closures. Positives: Unique thrill, Photogenic.

entries.name: Ben Thanh Market
entries.summary: The most famous landmark in Saigon is also a high-pressure sales zone. Vendors grab your arm, prices are marked up 300% for tourists, and the food section is overpriced compared to street stalls just one block away.

red_flags.evidence: "They grab your arm and won't let go. Very aggressive." (TripAdvisor)
"They asked 500k dong for a T-shirt. I bought it for 100k elsewhere." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's iconic and right in the center. Good for a quick look." (Lonely Planet)
"If you are good at haggling, you can find everything here." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Horrible experience. The ladies are so aggressive. Go to Tan Dinh market instead.
Good food if you know the prices, but be prepared to fight for a deal.

entries.embedding_text: Ben Thanh Market in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. market. tourist_trap. High-pressure sales zone. Vendors are physically aggressive and markups are 300%. Locals shop at Tan Dinh. Red flags: Physical aggression, The 'Tourist Tax'. Positives: Central landmark, One-stop souvenir shop.

entries.name: Finns Beach Club
entries.summary: A massive bamboo structure in Canggu that feels more like a crowded airport terminal than a beach club. Minimum spends are high, it is packed shoulder-to-shoulder, and the 'VIP' areas offer little respite from the chaos.

red_flags.evidence: "You have to commit to spending millions of rupiah just to sit on a towel." (The Bali Bible)
"The pool water was cloudy and full of drunk people. Zero relaxation." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Great DJ and sunset vibes if you like to party hard." (Instagram)
"Despite the crowds, the waiters were fast and friendly." (Google Maps)

sample_reviews.text: Soulless money machine. Go to La Brisa for a better vibe.
Expensive but the sunset view with a cocktail was nice. Just very busy.

entries.embedding_text: Finns Beach Club in Bali, Indonesia. bar. tourist_trap. Massive, overcrowded beach club in Canggu. Feels like an airport terminal. High minimum spends and cloudy pools. Red flags: Exorbitant minimum spend, Overcrowded pool. Positives: Party energy, Efficient staff.

entries.name: Warung Babi Guling Ibu Oka
entries.summary: Made legendary by Anthony Bourdain. Once a humble stall, it is now a commercial operation catering to busloads of tourists. The roast pig (Babi Guling) is still decent, but locals argue the skin is often cold and better versions exist at Pak Malen or Ibu Rambug.

red_flags.evidence: "Skin was chewy, not crispy. Felt like it was cooked hours ago." (Food Blog)
"Locals stopped coming years ago when the prices doubled." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "It put Babi Guling on the map for the world." (Eater)
"A safe, clean place to try the dish for the first time." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: It's fine, but Pak Malen is way better and spicier. Ibu Oka is for beginners.
Delicious pork! We arrived early and got the fresh skin.

entries.embedding_text: Warung Babi Guling Ibu Oka in Bali, Indonesia. restaurant. mixed. Made famous by Bourdain. Now commercialized and tourist-heavy. Pork is decent but often cold/chewy. Locals prefer Pak Malen. Red flags: Mass produced feel, Only tourists eat here. Positives: Cultural icon, Safe introduction.

entries.name: Rainbow Mountain (Vinicunca)
entries.summary: The ultimate 'Instagram vs Reality' trap. Photos show vibrant colors, but the reality is often a muddy, grey trek at dangerous altitude (5,200m) with hundreds of people. The colors are only visible under specific weather conditions.

red_flags.evidence: "If it rains or snows (which is often), it's just a brown mud hill. Zero colors." (TripAdvisor)
"Tour agencies push this on people who just arrived. Altitude sickness is rampant." (Travel Safety Blog)

positive_signals.evidence: "On a clear day, the striations are geologically fascinating." (NatGeo)
"The entrance fees go directly to the indigenous communities managing the land." (Local Guide)

sample_reviews.text: Heavily edited photos lied to me. It was grey, cold, and I threw up from altitude.
Hard hike but worth it for the view of the Red Valley nearby.

entries.embedding_text: Rainbow Mountain (Vinicunca) in Cusco, Peru. attraction. tourist_trap. Instagram vs Reality disappointment. Often muddy/grey unless weather is perfect. Dangerous altitude (5,200m) for unacclimatized tourists. Red flags: Weather dependency, Dangerous altitude. Positives: Unique geological formation, Supports local community.

entries.name: Central
entries.summary: Voted the #1 Restaurant in the World. It is expensive and difficult to book, but it is the opposite of a trap. The menu is a deep research project into Peru's biodiversity, executing flavors found nowhere else on earth.

red_flags.evidence: "You need to be online the second reservations open, months in advance." (Eater)
"A meal here costs a month's salary for a local." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The altitude-based menu is a masterpiece of edible geography." (World's 50 Best)
"They use ingredients from the Amazon and Andes that even locals haven't seen." (New York Times)

sample_reviews.text: It's an investment, but it changed how I understand food. Not just a meal, an expedition.
Proud that Peruvian food is on the world stage. Virgilio is a genius.

entries.embedding_text: Central in Lima, Peru. restaurant. local_gem. Voted #1 Restaurant in the World. Expensive and hard to book, but offers unmatched biodiversity research on a plate. Red flags: Booking is nearly impossible, Very expensive. Positives: Unmatched culinary innovation, Deeply Peruvian ingredients.

entries.name: Café del Mar
entries.summary: Occupies a prime spot on the historic city walls. You pay an entrance fee just to access the bar, the cocktails are watery and overpriced, and the service is notoriously arrogant. You are paying strictly for the sunset.

red_flags.evidence: "Paying a cover charge to enter a bar is ridiculous, and the drinks were bad." (TripAdvisor)
"Waiters act like they are doing you a favor. Ignored us for 30 minutes." (Google Maps)

positive_signals.evidence: "Okay, the view of the sunset over the Caribbean is admittedly perfect." (Lonely Planet)
"Sitting on the 400-year-old wall with the sea breeze is nice." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Buy a beer from a street vendor and sit on the wall 10 meters away for free. Same view.
Terrible drinks, but great photos. One time thing.

entries.embedding_text: Café del Mar in Cartagena, Colombia. bar. tourist_trap. Prime spot on city walls. Charging entrance fees for watery drinks and arrogant service. Paying strictly for the sunset. Red flags: Cover charge, Arrogant service. Positives: The Sunset View, Breezy historic setting.

entries.name: Andrés Carne de Res (Chía)
entries.summary: A 2,000-seat maximalist steakhouse and nightclub outside Bogota. It is chaotic, surreal, and expensive, but unlike its city branches, the original Chía location is a beloved pilgrimage site for locals celebrating birthdays.

red_flags.evidence: "It's a $30 Uber ride/hour drive from Bogota. You need a designated driver." (WikiTravel)
"Prices are high, you are paying for the show more than the steak." (Degusta)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's Alice in Wonderland meets a rave. There is nothing like it." (Eater)
"Every Bogotano has celebrated a birthday here. It's an institution." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Total madness. Confetti, actors, dancing on tables. The steak was actually good too.
Don't go to the DC location, go to Chia. It's the only real one.

entries.embedding_text: Andrés Carne de Res (Chía) in Bogota, Colombia. restaurant. local_gem. 2,000-seat maximalist steakhouse/nightclub. Chaotic, surreal, and beloved by locals for celebrations. Red flags: Far from city center, Expensive. Positives: Unmatched party vibe, Locals love it.

entries.name: Escadaria Selarón
entries.summary: A vibrant mosaic staircase created by artist Jorge Selarón. It is a stunning piece of public art, but the crowds are suffocating, making it nearly impossible to get a photo without 20 other people in it.

red_flags.evidence: "Expect to wait in line to take a photo on the main steps." (TripAdvisor)
"Do not wander off the stairs. The surrounding streets can be sketchy." (Local Safety Guide)

positive_signals.evidence: "The tiles from around the world are fascinating to look at close up." (Lonely Planet)
"It costs nothing and is an iconic symbol of Rio." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Beautiful art but ruined by the influencers. Go at 7am or don't bother.
Iconic. We found a tile from our home country!

entries.embedding_text: Escadaria Selarón in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. attraction. mixed. Vibrant mosaic staircase. Stunning public art, but suffocating crowds make photos difficult. Surrounding area can be unsafe. Red flags: Crowded photo struggle, Safety in surrounding area. Positives: Artistic detail, Free.

entries.name: Confeitaria Colombo
entries.summary: A grand cafe from 1894 with colossal mirrors and stained glass. It is a 'Time Trap'—the atmosphere is majestic, but the pastries and coffee are average and overpriced compared to modern bakeries.

red_flags.evidence: "The coxinha was dry and the coffee was bitter. You eat the decor." (Rio Times)
"Queue wrapped around the block in the heat." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "One of the most beautiful cafes in the world. A visual masterpiece." (Architectural Digest)
"It feels like the Belle Epoque. Historic value is undeniable." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Go for tea and look at the ceiling. Don't expect a gourmet meal.
Tourist trap with bad service. We waited 20 minutes for the bill.

entries.embedding_text: Confeitaria Colombo in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. cafe. mixed. Grand cafe from 1894. Majestic atmosphere, but pastries and coffee are average and overpriced. Red flags: Average food, Long queues. Positives: Stunning architecture, Living history.

entries.name: Jemaa el-Fnaa Food Stalls
entries.summary: The famous night market is a sensory overload of aggressive touts. The numbered food stalls serve pre-cooked, mediocre tagines often linked to 'Marrakech Belly' (food poisoning). Locals eat in the side streets, not the center.

red_flags.evidence: "Touts will physically block your path and guilt you into sitting." (Rough Guides)
"Food sits out all day. Known locally as the diarrhea lottery." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The smoke, the lights, the noise—it is a spectacle you must see (from a distance)." (NatGeo)
"The juice carts (separate from food stalls) are cheap and fresh." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Do not eat at the numbered stalls! We got sick. Go to a restaurant with a terrace instead.
Just buy the orange juice ($0.40) and walk around. The food is a scam.

entries.embedding_text: Jemaa el-Fnaa Food Stalls in Marrakech, Morocco. street_food. tourist_trap. Sensory overload of aggressive touts. Food is pre-cooked, mediocre, and linked to illness. Locals eat elsewhere. Red flags: Extreme harassment, Hygiene concerns. Positives: Incredible energy, Fresh Orange Juice Carts.

entries.name: Pyramids Camel Ride
entries.summary: Notorious for scams. Handlers will quote a low price to get on, then demand a fortune to let you get off. The animals are often mistreated, and the experience is high-stress rather than magical.

red_flags.evidence: "He refused to make the camel kneel down until I paid $50 extra." (TripAdvisor)
"Camels looked malnourished and were beaten." (PETA/Travel Blogs)

positive_signals.evidence: "It is the classic Egypt photo with the pyramids in the back." (Instagram)
"Riding where pharaohs walked is a nice thought." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Nightmare. I was harassed the entire time. Walk or take an Uber to the panorama point.
If you pre-book with a reputable guide, it's fine. Do not negotiate on the street.

entries.embedding_text: Pyramids Camel Ride in Cairo, Egypt. tour. tourist_trap. Notorious for 'hostage scams' (pay to get off). Animals often mistreated. High-stress experience. Red flags: Hostage scam, Animal welfare. Positives: Iconic photo op, Ancient transport.

entries.name: Sydney Fish Market
entries.summary: The largest fish market in the Southern Hemisphere is a chaotic, overpriced destination. While the seafood is fresh, it is cooked in heavy grease, served on styrofoam, and eaten while fighting off aggressive seagulls in a parking lot setting.

red_flags.evidence: "$30 for a greasy basket of fish and chips? You can get better at any beach shop." (Broadsheet)
"The birds are a menace. They snatch food from your hands." (Sydney Morning Herald)

positive_signals.evidence: "If you buy the raw oysters or sashimi, quality is top tier." (Timeout Sydney)
"The sheer variety of species on display is impressive." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Locals call it a trap. The new building might fix it, but for now, it's a dirty parking lot.
Loved the sashimi platter. Just avoid the deep fried stuff.

entries.embedding_text: Sydney Fish Market in Sydney, Australia. market. tourist_trap. Largest fish market in region but chaotic and overpriced. Cooked food is greasy, seagulls are aggressive. Red flags: Overpriced cooked food, Seagulls and crowding. Positives: Fresh oysters/Sashimi, Huge selection.

entries.name: Hobbiton Movie Set
entries.summary: Expensive ($90+ USD) and in the middle of nowhere, yet it consistently ranks as a highlight. The attention to detail is obsessive (real vegetable gardens), and the tour concludes with a complimentary ale at the Green Dragon Inn.

red_flags.evidence: "It is very expensive for a 2 hour walking tour." (TripAdvisor)
"It's a long drive from Auckland just for this." (Lonely Planet)

positive_signals.evidence: "The set is maintained to perfection. It feels real." (The One Ring)
"Even if you aren't a fan, the landscape is stunning." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: I expected a trap but I was blown away. The level of detail is insane.
Rushed through in a group, but the Green Dragon drink was a nice touch.

entries.embedding_text: Hobbiton Movie Set in Matamata, New Zealand. attraction. local_gem. Expensive and remote, but obsessive attention to detail makes it a highlight. Includes drink at Green Dragon Inn. Red flags: High ticket price, Remote location. Positives: Immaculate maintenance, Magical experience.

entries.name: Grand Bazaar
entries.summary: One of the oldest malls in the world, now a labyrinth of fake designer bags and overpriced lamps. Shopkeepers are aggressive, and prices are 3-4x higher than markets used by locals (like Kadıköy).

red_flags.evidence: "Spices cost 4x more here than at the Egyptian Bazaar." (Culinary Backstreets)
"Mostly counterfeit bags and cheap souvenirs made in China." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The painted ceilings and history are worth the walk." (Lonely Planet)
"4,000 shops. You can get lost for hours." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Go for the architecture, buy nothing. It's a rip-off city.
Fun to haggle if you know what you're doing, but exhausting.

entries.embedding_text: Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, Turkey. market. tourist_trap. Oldest mall in the world, now a labyrinth of fake goods and aggressive sellers. Prices are 3-4x higher than local markets. Red flags: Tourist markup, Fake goods. Positives: Architectural wonder, Endless browsing.

entries.name: Hafiz Mustafa 1864
entries.summary: Despite being in all the tourist centers (Sultanahmet, Taksim), this dessert chain maintains incredible quality. Their Baklava and Turkish Delight are fresh, using real honey and pistachios, and locals still buy gift boxes here.

red_flags.evidence: "More expensive than neighborhood spots, but you pay for consistency." (Istanbul Eats)
"Service can be slow due to the volume of customers." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The pistachio-to-dough ratio is perfect. Not too sweet." (Serious Eats)
"I always bring Hafiz Mustafa when visiting family abroad." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Best baklava I've ever had. Open 24/7 which is dangerous.
Touristy but quality. The milk puddings are underrated.

entries.embedding_text: Hafiz Mustafa 1864 in Istanbul, Turkey. cafe. local_gem. Dessert chain maintaining incredible quality despite tourist locations. Fresh Baklava and Turkish Delight. Locals buy gifts here. Red flags: Pricey for Istanbul, Busy/Chaotic. Positives: High quality ingredients, Reliable gift.

entries.name: Gardens by the Bay
entries.summary: A futuristic botanical garden that looks like a sci-fi movie set. While the Cloud Forest dome requires a ticket, the Supertree Grove is free. It manages to be a massive tourist attraction that is also genuinely beloved for its engineering and beauty.

red_flags.evidence: "During peak periods, you can wait up to an hour for the lift, missing 80% of the attraction." (Reddit)
"Cloud Forest is amazing, Flower Dome is just a greenhouse." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The world's tallest indoor waterfall is breathtaking." (Condé Nast Traveler)
"You can see the Supertree light show for free every night." (Timeout)

sample_reviews.text: Avatar in real life. The Cloud Forest is worth every penny.
Bring a picnic and sit under the Supertrees. Best free activity in SG.

entries.embedding_text: Gardens by the Bay in Singapore. attraction. local_gem. Futuristic botanical garden. Cloud Forest is a marvel; Supertree Grove is free. Massive attraction but genuinely beloved for engineering and beauty. Red flags: Extreme peak crowds. Positives: Cloud Forest waterfall, Free outdoor areas.

entries.name: Bukchon Hanok Village
entries.summary: A historic neighborhood of traditional Korean houses (Hanok) dating back 600 years. It is visually stunning, but the 'over-tourism' has led to conflict with residents who patrol the streets shushing tourists, creating a tense atmosphere.

red_flags.evidence: "Residents wear yellow vests and tell you to be quiet. It feels unwelcoming." (Korea Herald)
"You can't go inside most houses. It's just walking up a hill." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The juxtaposition of ancient roofs and modern skyscrapers is unique." (Visit Seoul)
"The view from the top of the hill overlooking Seoul is worth the climb." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Beautiful but I felt guilty being there. Signs everywhere saying 'Be Quiet'.
Go early (8am) before the bus crowds. It's peaceful then.

entries.embedding_text: Bukchon Hanok Village in Seoul, South Korea. attraction. mixed. Historic neighborhood of traditional houses. Visually stunning, but over-tourism creates tense atmosphere with residents (shushing). Red flags: Hostile atmosphere, Just facades. Positives: Preserved architecture, Great views.

entries.name: Leopold Cafe
entries.summary: Immortalized by the novel 'Shantaram' and a site of the 2008 terror attacks. It is packed with tourists seeking the literary connection. The food is average continental/Indian, but the bullet holes in the walls serve as a chilling historical marker.

red_flags.evidence: "Food is overpriced and mediocre. You pay for the Shantaram vibe." (Mumbai Mag)
"Waiters want you to eat and leave. Very noisy." (Zomato)

positive_signals.evidence: "Seeing the bullet holes from 2008 is a powerful, somber experience." (BBC Travel)
"A great place to meet other backpackers and swap stories." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Read the book, went for a beer. It's loud and crowded, but I'm glad I went once.
Overrated. Go to Cafe Mondegar nearby for better vibes and art.

entries.embedding_text: Leopold Cafe in Mumbai, India. cafe. mixed. Immortalized by 'Shantaram' and 2008 attacks. Packed with tourists. Food is average, but bullet holes in walls are a powerful historical marker. Red flags: Average food, Rushed service. Positives: Historical marker, Traveller hub.

entries.name: Fushimi Inari Taisha
entries.summary: The famous 'thousands of red gates' shrine. While the base is swarming with Instagrammers, it is a massive mountain complex. If you hike 30 minutes up, the crowds vanish, leaving a spiritual and atmospheric experience.

red_flags.evidence: "The entrance is a mosh pit of selfie sticks." (Japan Guide)
"Water costs double halfway up the mountain. Bring your own." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The further you go, the more magical it gets. Silence and red gates." (Matcha-JP)
"Open 24/7. Go at night for a spooky, empty experience." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Don't stop at the bottom! Hike to the crossroads for the view and solitude.
Too many people at the start, but it's iconic for a reason.

entries.embedding_text: Fushimi Inari Taisha in Kyoto, Japan. attraction. local_gem. Famous red gates shrine. Base is crowded, but hiking 30 mins up reveals a spiritual, empty experience. Open 24/7 and free. Red flags: Base is overcrowded. Positives: Spiritual hike, Always open and free.

entries.name: Desa Potato Head
entries.summary: More than just a beach club, it's a creative village with a focus on sustainability. While still expensive and busy, the architecture (made of antique shutters) and zero-waste initiatives give it a soul that competitors lack.

red_flags.evidence: "You have to arrive at 10am to get a bed, or pay for VIP." (The Bali Bible)
"Drinks are London prices in Indonesia." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "They are zero-waste. The furniture is recycled plastic. Impressive." (Wallpaper*)
"The colosseum of shutters is a design icon." (Design Boom)

sample_reviews.text: Best sunset spot. The music is chill, not aggressive like Finns.
Great vibe but be prepared to pay. Food is small portions.

entries.embedding_text: Desa Potato Head in Bali, Indonesia. bar. mixed. Creative village/beach club. Expensive and busy, but stands out with antique shutter architecture and zero-waste sustainability initiatives. Red flags: Waitlist for daybeds, Expensive cocktails. Positives: Sustainability focus, Architectural gem.

entries.name: The Temple Bar
entries.summary: The most famous pub in Dublin is also the most expensive. It charges 'tourist prices' (€10+ for a pint) that increase as the night goes on. Locals avoid it entirely, citing the fake 'trad' music and crushing crowds.

red_flags.evidence: "They charge nearly €11 for a pint of Guinness. It's a tax on ignorance." (Dublin Live)
"It's Disneyland for drinking. No actual Irish person drinks here." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The live music is constant and the crowd is always happy (if drunk)." (TripAdvisor)
"The red facade with hanging flowers is the classic Dublin photo." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Robbery in broad daylight. Go to The Palace Bar or Grogan's for a real pint.
Expensive? Yes. Fun? Absolutely. The band played Galway Girl three times.

entries.embedding_text: The Temple Bar in Dublin, Ireland. bar. tourist_trap. Most famous pub in Dublin, charging €10+ for a pint. Locals avoid due to price gouging and fake atmosphere. Red flags: Price gouging, Artificial atmosphere. Positives: Lively energy, Iconic exterior.

entries.name: Guinness Storehouse
entries.summary: Dublin's #1 attraction is essentially a 7-story commercial for beer. It is expensive and crowded, but the production value is high, and the Gravity Bar view (with a complimentary pint) is genuinely one of the best in the city.

red_flags.evidence: "€30 to walk through a museum about a company. It feels like a long ad." (Rick Steves)
"Packed like sardines. Hard to enjoy the exhibits." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The 360-degree view of Dublin is unmatched, especially with a fresh pint." (Lonely Planet)
"Slick, modern, and interactive. They know how to put on a show." (Irish Times)

sample_reviews.text: It's a trap, but a good one. The view at the top makes the ticket price swallowable.
Overrated. Just go to a pub. You don't learn much about brewing.

entries.embedding_text: Guinness Storehouse in Dublin, Ireland. attraction. mixed. Dublin's #1 attraction. Expensive 7-story commercial, but high production value and Gravity Bar views make it worth it for many. Red flags: Expensive corporate tour, Crowds. Positives: Gravity Bar view, Well-designed experience.

entries.name: Trdelník Stands (Old Town)
entries.summary: Sold as 'Traditional Old Bohemian Pastry', this chimney cake is actually a Hungarian import popularized in Prague for tourists in the 2000s. It is overpriced, messy, and locals never eat it.

red_flags.evidence: "It's not Czech. It's a marketing scam invented for tourists." (Honest Guide Prague)
"150 CZK for dough and sugar? You can get a full lunch for that." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The smell of cinnamon sugar wafting through the square is enticing." (Travel Blog)
"Looks great filled with ice cream for photos." (Instagram)

sample_reviews.text: Don't buy the 'chimney cake'. It's a tourist tax. Get a Vetruas instead.
Delicious but very messy. The ice cream melts everywhere.

entries.embedding_text: Trdelník Stands (Old Town) in Prague, Czech Republic. street_food. tourist_trap. Sold as 'Traditional Bohemian', but actually a recent marketing invention. Overpriced and ignored by locals. Red flags: Fake tradition, Overpriced sugar dough. Positives: Smells good, Instagrammable.

entries.name: Heineken Experience
entries.summary: A loud, crowded, interactive commercial. Unlike Guinness, this feels more like a frat party with sticky floors and aggressive branding. Beer aficionados find the brewing info shallow.

red_flags.evidence: "Full of drunk stag parties shouting. Unpleasant." (TripAdvisor)
"€23 entry is steep just to drink two small beers." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "If you are with a group of friends wanting to party, it's a good start." (Travel Blog)
"The old brewery building itself is impressive architecture." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Skip it. Go to Brouwerij 't IJ under the windmill for better beer and vibes.
We had fun making custom bottles. A bit commercial but entertaining.

entries.embedding_text: Heineken Experience in Amsterdam, Netherlands. attraction. tourist_trap. Loud, crowded commercial that feels like a frat party. Shallow brewing info and expensive. Locals prefer microbreweries. Red flags: Rowdy atmosphere, Expensive for what it is. Positives: Fun for groups, Historic building.

entries.name: Oia Sunset View Points
entries.summary: The world's most famous sunset is a contact sport. Thousands of tourists cram into narrow alleys hours in advance. When the sun sets, people clap. It is claustrophobic, stressful, and ruins the romance.

red_flags.evidence: "You are crushed against strangers. I saw people fighting over spots." (Santorini Dave)
"Traffic leaving Oia after sunset is a gridlock nightmare." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "If you can block out the people, the view of the caldera is world-class." (NatGeo)
"It costs nothing if you just stand on the castle walls." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Horrific. Like being in a mosh pit. Watch the sunset from Imerovigli instead.
Beautiful, but the clapping when the sun went down was weird.

entries.embedding_text: Oia Sunset View Points in Santorini, Greece. attraction. tourist_trap. The world's most famous sunset is a claustrophobic contact sport. Extreme crowding and traffic gridlock ruin the romance. Red flags: Extreme overcrowding, Impossible logistics. Positives: Undeniably beautiful, Technically free.

entries.name: Plaka Stairs Restaurants
entries.summary: Restaurants on the Mnisikleous stairs rely on aggressive touts and the picturesque setting. The food (moussaka, souvlaki) is often pre-cooked and microwaved, while prices are double those found just a few blocks away.

red_flags.evidence: "Waiters will practically drag you to a table. It's harassment." (Matt Barrett's Greece Guide)
"Moussaka was cold in the middle. Clearly frozen." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Sitting on the steps with music playing is a vibe, even if the food sucks." (Reddit)
"Convenient stop after the Acropolis." (Google Maps)

sample_reviews.text: Classic trap. Expensive, bad food, rude service. Walk 10 minutes to Psyri.
We paid for the location. The live music was nice.

entries.embedding_text: Plaka Stairs Restaurants in Athens, Greece. restaurant. tourist_trap. Restaurants rely on aggressive touts and setting. Food is often pre-cooked/microwaved; prices are doubled. Red flags: Aggressive dragging, Microwaved food. Positives: Picturesque setting, Near Acropolis.

entries.name: Ocean Drive Restaurants
entries.summary: Infamous for giant 'bulldog' margaritas and hidden fees. Menus often don't list prices for specials, leading to $50 drink bills. The food is mediocre cafeteria quality masked by neon lights and loud music.

red_flags.evidence: "They charged me $60 for two drinks. Prices weren't on the menu." (Miami Herald)
"Paella was yellow rice and frozen shrimp. Inedible." (Yelp)

positive_signals.evidence: "Best spot to watch the supercars and crazy outfits." (Travel Blog)
"The backdrop of the Art Deco hotels is iconic." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: SCAM. Automatic 20% service charge plus a 'resort fee' on a salad. Never again.
Fun for a drink if you know you're getting ripped off. Don't eat.

entries.embedding_text: Ocean Drive Restaurants in Miami, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Infamous for giant margaritas and hidden fees ($50 drinks). Mediocre food masked by neon lights. Red flags: Hidden prices/fees, Mediocre food. Positives: People watching, Art Deco views.

entries.name: Joe's Stone Crab
entries.summary: An institution since 1913. Yes, it is expensive and difficult to get a table, but the stone crabs are sustainably harvested and world-class. Locals respect it as the one 'famous' place that delivers on quality.

red_flags.evidence: "No reservations means waiting 2 hours at the bar." (Eater Miami)
"Market price for claws can be shocking ($100+)." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Sweet, cold, and perfect with the mustard sauce. Unbeatable." (The Infatuation)
"Tuxedoed waiters who know the menu inside out." (Miami New Times)

sample_reviews.text: Go for lunch to avoid the wait. The fried chicken is the secret cheap winner.
It lives up to the hype. The key lime pie is legendary.

entries.embedding_text: Joe's Stone Crab in Miami, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Institution since 1913. Expensive with long waits, but sustainably harvested stone crabs are world-class. Locals respect the quality. Red flags: Long wait times, Expensive. Positives: Best stone crabs, Old school service.

entries.name: 360 The Restaurant (CN Tower)
entries.summary: Rotating restaurants are usually traps, but 360 offers a hack: the prix-fixe meal includes the tower elevation ticket. The food is decent (Canadian ingredients) and it lets you skip the elevator line, making it a decent value proposition.

red_flags.evidence: "Food is fine, but you are paying $80 for the rotation." (Toronto Life)
"Standard banquet hall food. Nothing adventurous." (Yelp)

positive_signals.evidence: "Spending $75 on dinner is better than $45 just for the elevator." (Reddit)
"Watching the sunset over Lake Ontario is magical." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Smartest way to see the CN Tower. Skip the lines, get a decent meal.
Steak was overcooked. Service was slow. View was 10/10.

entries.embedding_text: 360 The Restaurant (CN Tower) in Toronto, Canada. restaurant. mixed. Rotating restaurant that acts as a 'hack': meal includes tower elevation ticket, skipping lines. Food is decent but safe; you pay for the view. Red flags: Paying for the view, Safe boring menu. Positives: Includes tower entry, Unbeatable view.

entries.name: Livraria Lello
entries.summary: Rumored to be the inspiration for Harry Potter (debunked by JK Rowling), this bookstore now charges an entrance fee. It is so crowded you cannot browse books, functioning purely as a selfie factory.

red_flags.evidence: "It's a mosh pit. You are shoved along a path." (Rick Steves)
"JK Rowling confirmed she never visited it. The connection is a myth." (Publico)

positive_signals.evidence: "The red staircase and stained glass are undeniably gorgeous." (Architectural Digest)
"The €5 entry is deductible if you buy a book." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: A bookshop you pay to enter and can't read in? Absurd. Trap.
Go right at opening. It is beautiful, but the HP fans are annoying.

entries.embedding_text: Livraria Lello in Porto, Portugal. attraction. tourist_trap. Bookstore charging entrance fee due to debunked Harry Potter connection. Stunning interior but unbearable crowds make browsing impossible. Red flags: Unbearable crowds, False marketing. Positives: Stunning interior, Voucher system.

entries.name: Blue Lagoon
entries.summary: Iceland's most famous site is essentially man-made wastewater from a geothermal plant. It is expensive ($100+) and often closes due to volcanic activity. While unique, locals view it as an industrial trap, preferring Sky Lagoon.

red_flags.evidence: "It's not a natural spring. It's runoff from the power plant next door." (Guide to Iceland)
"Closed multiple times in 2024/2025 due to nearby eruptions. Check status daily." (Icelandic Met Office)

positive_signals.evidence: "The contrast of blue water and black lava is stunning." (NatGeo)
"Facilities are clean, modern, and efficient." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Go to Sky Lagoon instead. Closer to Reykjavik and feels more natural.
It was pricey but relaxing before our flight. The silica mask was fun.

entries.embedding_text: Blue Lagoon in Grindavik, Iceland. attraction. mixed. Expensive ($100+) man-made pool frequently closed by volcanic activity. Luxurious infrastructure and unique visuals, but locals view it as an industrial trap. Red flags: Industrial runoff, Frequent volcanic closures. Positives: Iconic visuals, Well organized.

entries.name: St. Lawrence Market
entries.summary: Named the best food market in the world by NatGeo. While tourists visit, it remains a functioning market for locals. The Peameal Bacon sandwich at Carousel Bakery is a genuine city icon.

red_flags.evidence: "Saturdays are a zoo. Hard to move." (BlogTO)
"Closed Sundays and Mondays. Catches tourists off guard." (Google Maps)

positive_signals.evidence: "The sandwich at Carousel is the real deal. Anthony Bourdain loved it." (Eater)
"I buy my cheese and meat here weekly." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Carousel Bakery bacon sandwich is a must. Simple, salty, perfect.
Great vibe, lots of free samples. The mustard store is cool.

entries.embedding_text: St. Lawrence Market in Toronto, Canada. market. local_gem. Functioning market for locals and tourists. Peameal Bacon sandwich is a genuine icon. Red flags: Crowded weekends, Limited hours. Positives: Authentic Peameal Bacon, Locals shop here.

entries.name: Duke's Waikiki
entries.summary: The ultimate beachfront tourist spot. It is packed, loud, and commercial, but the Hula Pie is legendary and the Sunday live music on the sand is a genuinely fun, quintessential Hawaiian experience.

red_flags.evidence: "Wait can be 2 hours for a table. It's a factory." (Yelp)
"Fish tacos were dry. You pay for the location." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The Hula Pie is massive and delicious. Worth the stop alone." (Hawaii Magazine)
"Barefoot bar on the sand with live music. Hard to beat." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Touristy? Yes. Did I love it? Yes. Get the pie and a Mai Tai.
Food is mediocre Applebee's quality. Just go for drinks.

entries.embedding_text: Duke's Waikiki in Honolulu, USA. restaurant. mixed. Ultimate beachfront tourist spot. Packed and commercial with average mains, but Hula Pie and Sunday live music create a fun, quintessential experience. Red flags: Wait times, Average mains. Positives: Hula Pie, Beach party vibe.

entries.name: Place du Tertre Restaurants
entries.summary: The artist square in Montmartre. Restaurants here serve some of the worst food in Paris (frozen onion soup, rubbery duck) at exorbitant prices, relying on the 'Amélie' fantasy.

red_flags.evidence: "Not a single fresh ingredient. It's heated up bags." (Le Figaro)
"Pushy portrait artists will start drawing you without asking then demand money." (Rick Steves)

positive_signals.evidence: "It looks like the painting of Paris you have in your head." (Lonely Planet)
"Right next to Sacré-Cœur." (Google Maps)

sample_reviews.text: Worst meal in Paris. €12 for a coke. Rude waiter.
Very romantic setting if you ignore the food quality.

entries.embedding_text: Place du Tertre Restaurants in Paris, France. restaurant. tourist_trap. Artist square in Montmartre. Serves worst food in Paris (frozen/industrial) at exorbitant prices. Pushy portrait artists. Red flags: Frozen industrial food, Sketchy artists. Positives: Bohemian aesthetic, Heart of Montmartre.

entries.name: L'Antica Pizzeria da Michele
entries.summary: Made famous by 'Eat Pray Love'. Despite the hour-long lines and tourist hype, it remains staunchly authentic: only two pizza choices (Marinara/Margherita), low prices (€5), and world-class dough.

red_flags.evidence: "You have to fight through a crowd just to get a ticket number." (Eater)
"You eat fast and get out. Not a place to linger." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The crust is soft, chewy, and charred perfectly. It defines the genre." (Serious Eats)
"€5 for a Michelin-recognized pizza is a miracle." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: The wait is hell but the pizza is heaven. Don't expect fancy service.
There are better pizzerias in Naples without the line (Starita, Sorbillo), but this is history.

entries.embedding_text: L'Antica Pizzeria da Michele in Naples, Italy. restaurant. local_gem. Famous 'Eat Pray Love' spot. Chaos and lines, but authentically cheap (€5) and serves benchmark Neapolitan pizza. Red flags: Ticket system chaos, Rushed dining. Positives: Benchmark Neapolitan Pizza, Incredibly cheap.

entries.name: Trevi Fountain
entries.summary: A masterpiece of Baroque art that is almost impossible to enjoy. The crowd density is dangerous, pickpockets are rampant, and guards blow whistles constantly. New entry fees and barriers are planned for 2025 to manage the chaos.

red_flags.evidence: "You can't even see the water over the wall of influencers." (Reddit)
"Barriers installed in late 2024. A €2 entry fee pilot program starts in 2025." (Travel Weekly Asia)

positive_signals.evidence: "Go at 6am. It is empty and breathtaking." (Lonely Planet)
"The scale and detail of the sculpture are unmatched." (Art History Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Beautiful but stressful. Whistles blowing, people shoving. Go at night.
Rome local here: I avoid this square at all costs unless it's 4am.

entries.embedding_text: Trevi Fountain in Rome, Italy. attraction. tourist_trap. Baroque masterpiece ruined by dangerous crowd density and pickpockets. New entry fees/barriers planned for 2025. Red flags: Crushing crowds, Access restrictions/Entry fees. Positives: Magical at dawn, Artistic masterpiece.

entries.name: Fisherman's Bastion
entries.summary: A neo-Gothic terrace offering the best views of Parliament. The lower decks are free, but they charge for the upper balconies which offer the *exact same view*. It is crowded but essential for the panorama.

red_flags.evidence: "Don't pay for the upper level. The view is identical from the free section." (Rick Steves)
"Filled with people in ballgowns doing photoshoots at 7am." (Instagram vs Reality)

positive_signals.evidence: "The view of the Parliament across the Danube is iconic." (Lonely Planet)
"It looks like a Disney castle but better." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: The bar at the top is a trap, but the structure itself is stunning.
Save your money, stay on the lower level. Same view, free.

entries.embedding_text: Fisherman's Bastion in Budapest, Hungary. attraction. mixed. Neo-Gothic terrace with best views of Parliament. Lower decks are free; upper paid decks are a 'scam' (same view). Red flags: Paid balconies are a scam, Crowded with photoshoots. Positives: Best view in Budapest, Fairytale architecture.

entries.name: New York Café
entries.summary: Self-proclaimed 'Most Beautiful Café in the World'. The interior is a gold-leaf palace, but you wait an hour in line to pay €10 for a mediocre cappuccino. It is a visual museum where you are forced to buy overpriced refreshments.

red_flags.evidence: "€25 for a cake and coffee in a city where that usually costs €5." (Offbeat Budapest)
"The schnitzel was dry and the coffee lukewarm." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "It is undeniably breathtaking. Baroque opulence everywhere." (Architectural Digest)
"The live gypsy band adds to the atmosphere." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Beautiful to look at, painful to pay for. One time experience.
Tourist factory. Go to Café Gerbeaud instead.

entries.embedding_text: New York Café in Budapest, Hungary. cafe. tourist_trap. Gold-leaf palace interior. Visual museum with hour-long lines and exorbitant prices for mediocre food (€10 coffee). Red flags: Exorbitant prices, Average food. Positives: Stunning interior, Live classical music.

entries.name: Dubrovnik City Walls
entries.summary: Walking the walls is the highlight of Dubrovnik, but prices have tripled in recent years (now ~€35-40). It is expensive and crowded with Game of Thrones fans, but the views of the terracotta roofs and sea are irreplaceable.

red_flags.evidence: "Prices have gone from €15 to €35-40 in a few years. It feels exploitative." (Croatia Week)
"In summer it is a death march. No shade and packed." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The perspective of the Old Town is unmatched. Essential." (Lonely Planet)
"One of the best preserved medieval walls in Europe." (UNESCO)

sample_reviews.text: Go at 8am or 6pm. Midday is suicide. Expensive but you have to do it.
Rip off. Just go to the Buza Bar for a view.

entries.embedding_text: Dubrovnik City Walls in Dubrovnik, Croatia. attraction. mixed. Essential experience for views, but prices have tripled (~€35-40) and summer crowds are brutal. Exploitative pricing but irreplaceable views. Red flags: Aggressive price hikes, No shade/Heat. Positives: World-class views, Preserved fortification.

entries.name: Game of Thrones Tours
entries.summary: Hundreds of unauthorized guides leading groups to the 'Walk of Shame' stairs. They block the streets, shout incorrect history, and sell cheap merch. Locals hate how it has overshadowed the city's real history.

red_flags.evidence: "Guides talk about dragons instead of the 1991 siege or Ragusa history." (Dubrovnik Times)
"Locals are blocked from entering their homes by tour groups." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Seeing King's Landing in real life was a dream." (TripAdvisor)
"Even if the stories are fake, the fortresses are real and beautiful." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Guide had a printed photo album and just pointed at steps. Could have done it myself.
Please learn the real history of Dubrovnik. It is more interesting than the show.

entries.embedding_text: Game of Thrones Tours in Dubrovnik, Croatia. tour. tourist_trap. Unauthorized guides block streets and shout fictional history, overshadowing the city's real heritage. Locals hate the nuisance. Red flags: Fictional history, Nuisance to residents. Positives: Fun for superfans, Takes you to nice spots.

entries.name: 360 CHICAGO (John Hancock)
entries.summary: While the Willis (Sears) Tower is the famous trap, locals prefer the Hancock Center. It offers better views (you can see the skyline including the Willis Tower), has a bar (Tilt), and shorter lines.

red_flags.evidence: "The 'Tilt' feature is over in 30 seconds. Not worth the extra cost." (Chicago Tribune)
"Still a tourist spot, so expect lines on weekends." (Google Maps)

positive_signals.evidence: "You get to see the actual skyline because you aren't in the tallest building." (Reddit)
"Grab a drink at the CloudBar. Much more relaxed than the Skydeck." (TimeOut Chicago)

sample_reviews.text: Skip the Skydeck. Go to Hancock, get a drink, enjoy the view.
Tilt was a gimmick, but the view of the lake and city is unbeatable.

entries.embedding_text: 360 CHICAGO (John Hancock) in Chicago, USA. attraction. local_gem. Locals prefer this over Willis Tower. Better views (includes skyline), shorter lines, and has a bar. Red flags: Tilt attraction is short, Elevator lines. Positives: Better views than Willis, Bar atmosphere.

entries.name: Café Majestic
entries.summary: One of the most beautiful Belle Époque cafes in the world. However, prices are 4x the local average (€6 for coffee) and you are paying strictly for the mirrors and chandeliers. The 'French Toast' (Rabanadas) is famous but pricey.

red_flags.evidence: "Most expensive coffee in Porto. You pay for the architecture." (Timeout Porto)
"Line down the street just for a coffee." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The interior is a masterpiece of Art Nouveau. Stunning." (Lonely Planet)
"Their version of french toast wrapped in egg custard is delicious." (Serious Eats)

sample_reviews.text: Go once for the photo, order one coffee, then leave. Food is average.
The French Toast was the best I've ever had, even if it cost €8.

entries.embedding_text: Café Majestic in Porto, Portugal. cafe. mixed. Belle Époque masterpiece. Prices are 4x local average (€6 coffee). Paying for mirrors and chandeliers. 'Rabanadas' (French Toast) is famous. Red flags: Tourist markup, Queue. Positives: Architectural gem, Rabanadas.

entries.name: Hallstatt Village
entries.summary: The poster child for over-tourism. A village of 700 people receiving 1 million visitors. It is impossible to walk, drones buzz everywhere, and locals have erected fences to block views to stop selfies. It is beautiful but broken.

red_flags.evidence: "It feels like a theme park, not a village. You are shoulder to shoulder." (BBC Travel)
"Residents are putting up barriers to stop photographers. They hate us." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The view of the church spire against the lake is iconic." (NatGeo)
"The salt mine tour up the hill is actually educational and less crowded." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Ruined by its own fame. Buses everywhere. Go to nearby Gosau instead.
Beautiful if you arrive at 6am. By 9am it is hell.

entries.embedding_text: Hallstatt Village in Hallstatt, Austria. attraction. tourist_trap. Poster child for over-tourism. Impossible crowds, drones, and hostile locals erecting barriers. Beautiful but broken. Red flags: Extreme overtourism, Hostile locals. Positives: Postcard perfect, Salt mines.

entries.name: Antico Caffè Greco
entries.summary: Rome's oldest cafe (1760) near the Spanish Steps. Like many historic Italian cafes, there is a massive price difference between standing at the bar (€2) and sitting at a table (€12). It is a museum of literary history.

red_flags.evidence: "Charged €12 for a cappuccino because we sat down. Rookie mistake." (Fodor's)
"Waiters in tuxedos can be snooty if you aren't dressed up." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Keats and Byron drank here. The history on the walls is real." (Rome Toolkit)
"Stand at the bar and you pay normal Rome prices for excellent coffee." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Stand at the bar! Do not sit! Coffee is great, atmosphere is moody.
Tourist trap prices. €30 for two coffees and a pastry.

entries.embedding_text: Antico Caffè Greco in Rome, Italy. cafe. mixed. Rome's oldest cafe (1760). Massive price gap between standing (€2) and sitting (€12). Literary history (Keats, Byron). Red flags: Table service surcharge, Stiff service. Positives: Literary haunt, Bar price is standard.

entries.name: Lune Croissanterie
entries.summary: Described by the New York Times as making 'the finest croissants in the world'. The warehouse setting looks like an Apple store for pastry. Despite lines at 7 AM and high prices ($10+ per pastry), the engineering perfection of the dough justifies the hype.

red_flags.evidence: "If you arrive after 10am, the specials are gone. Frustrating." (Broadsheet)
"$14 for a twice-baked croissant is steep, even for Melbourne." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The lamination is scientifically perfect. Shatteringly crisp." (New York Times)
"Watching the chefs work in the glass cube is mesmerizing theater." (Good Food)

sample_reviews.text: I wanted to hate it because of the hype. I failed. The almond croissant is a masterpiece.
Good, but not 'wait in the rain for an hour' good. It's just butter and flour.

entries.embedding_text: Lune Croissanterie in Melbourne, Australia. cafe. local_gem. 'Finest croissants in the world'. Warehouse setting, high prices, and early lines. Engineering perfection of the dough justifies the hype. Red flags: Sold out early, Expensive pastry. Positives: Technical perfection, The 'Cube' experience.

entries.name: Fergburger
entries.summary: A burger joint with a cult following so large the queue often blocks the sidewalk. While the burgers are massive (size of a plate) and tasty, locals argue the 45+ minute wait isn't worth it when neighboring Devil Burger is just as good.

red_flags.evidence: "Line is insane at all hours. You wait 45 mins just to order." (Lonely Planet)
"Locals go to Devil Burger or Red Star. Same quality, no line." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The Fergburger is the size of a human head. Great value." (Travel Blog)
"Waiting in line with a beer is part of the Queenstown experience." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Overhyped. The bun fell apart and it was just a big burger. Go next door.
Best burger I've ever had after a hike. The 'Cockadoodle Oink' is legendary.

entries.embedding_text: Fergburger in Queenstown, New Zealand. restaurant. mixed. Cult burger joint with massive lines. Burgers are huge and tasty, but locals prefer Devil Burger to avoid the 45-minute wait. Red flags: The Queue, Better alternatives exist. Positives: Huge portions, Social vibe.

entries.name: Burj Khalifa (At The Top)
entries.summary: The tallest building in the world charges a fortune ($50-$150) for an elevator ride. The standard 'At The Top' ticket only goes to floor 124, while the 'SKY' ticket (floor 148) costs double. Views are often obscured by haze or sandstorms.

red_flags.evidence: "You pay premium for 'At The Top' but you are only halfway up the building." (Arabian Business)
"Queued for 1 hour to go up, and 1 hour to come down." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "You can say you stood on the world's tallest building." (Lonely Planet)
"The elevator ride itself is an engineering marvel, moving 10m/sec." (Official Site)

sample_reviews.text: A view of sand and highways. Not worth the money or the wait.
Go at sunset. Seeing the fountains from above is cool.

entries.embedding_text: Burj Khalifa (At The Top) in Dubai, UAE. attraction. tourist_trap. Tallest building in world. expensive elevator ride ($50+) to a deck that isn't the top. Haze often obscures views. Red flags: Deceptive marketing, Lines everywhere. Positives: Bragging rights, Fast elevator.

entries.name: Mahane Yehuda Market
entries.summary: The 'Shuk' is the beating heart of Jerusalem. By day, a chaotic produce market; by night, a trendy bar scene. While some stalls are gentrifying and raising prices, the energy and food quality (halva, rugelach) remain authentic.

red_flags.evidence: "Friday afternoon before Shabbat is a crush. Avoid if you have anxiety." (TimeOut Israel)
"Stalls at the main entrance charge double. Go deep inside." (Local Guide)

positive_signals.evidence: "The way it turns into a bar scene at night is unique in the world." (Eater)
"The chocolate rugelach from Marzipan Bakery are gooey perfection." (Serious Eats)

sample_reviews.text: Best vibes in the city. Grab a beer and sit on a crate.
Crowded and loud, but the food is incredible. Try the Iraqi Kubbeh.

entries.embedding_text: Mahane Yehuda Market in Jerusalem, Israel. market. local_gem. Chaotic produce market by day, trendy bar scene by night. Authentic energy and food (halva, rugelach) despite some gentrification. Red flags: Aggressive crowds (Friday), Tourist pricing at entrances. Positives: Nightlife transformation, Marzipan Rugelach.

entries.name: Alcatraz Night Tour
entries.summary: While Alcatraz is a major attraction, the 'Night Tour' is a distinct, superior experience. It is limited capacity, includes areas closed during the day (like the hospital), and features compelling guided talks. Locals actually recommend this.

red_flags.evidence: "Tickets sell out 3 months in advance. Impossible to get last minute." (SF Gate)
"It is freezing on the island at night. Dress for winter." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Fewer people and the sunset over the Golden Gate make it hauntingly beautiful." (Lonely Planet)
"The audio tour voiced by former inmates is chilling and award-winning." (Travel Channel)

sample_reviews.text: I'm an SF native and I've done the night tour 3 times. It never gets old.
Spooky, informative, and amazing views of the city lights. Worth the planning.

entries.embedding_text: Alcatraz Night Tour in San Francisco, USA. tour. local_gem. Distinct from day tour. Limited capacity, access to closed areas, and haunting atmosphere. Locals recommend it. Red flags: Hard to book, Cold/Windy. Positives: Spooky and intimate, Excellent audio guide.

entries.name: Fisherman's Wharf
entries.summary: The epicenter of SF tourism and arguably the worst food in the city. Souvenir shops selling 'fog' in a can, overpriced clam chowder in stale bread bowls, and aggressive buskers. Locals treat it like a quarantine zone.

red_flags.evidence: "Restaurants here serve frozen seafood to people who don't know better." (SF Chronicle)
"Busker scares people for money. Aggressive panhandling." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The sea lions are actually cute and free to watch." (Lonely Planet)
"The antique arcade museum is the only redeeming quality." (Atlas Obscura)

sample_reviews.text: Avoid unless you want to be surrounded by slow walkers and overpriced trash.
Fun for the kids to see the sea lions, but we ate elsewhere.

entries.embedding_text: Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco, USA. attraction. tourist_trap. Epicenter of SF tourism. Souvenir shops, overpriced stale chowder, and aggressive buskers. Locals avoid. Red flags: Terrible food quality, Bushman scam. Positives: Sea Lions at Pier 39, Musee Mecanique.

entries.name: Swan Oyster Depot
entries.summary: A counter-only seafood institution since 1912. There is always a line, it closes early, and the staff are brusque, but the Dungeness crab and sashmi are undeniably fresh. It is the antithesis of Fisherman's Wharf.

red_flags.evidence: "Expect to wait 1-2 hours in line on Polk Street." (Eater SF)
"Closes at 5:30pm. Lunch only basically." (Google Maps)

positive_signals.evidence: "The crab back (fat) dip is the best seafood bite in the city." (Anthony Bourdain)
"No reservations, cash only, banter with the servers. Real SF." (Bon Appetit)

sample_reviews.text: Worth the wait. The Sicilian sashimi is to die for.
Expensive for a counter, but the quality is unmatched.

entries.embedding_text: Swan Oyster Depot in San Francisco, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Counter-only seafood institution since 1912. Long lines and limited hours, but Dungeness crab is unmatched. Antithesis of Fisherman's Wharf. Red flags: The wait, Limited hours. Positives: Freshness, Old school vibe.

entries.name: Museum of Ice Cream
entries.summary: The pioneer of the 'Instagram Museum'. It is not a museum; it is a series of colorful backdrops for selfies with a sprinkle pool made of plastic. Tickets are expensive ($40+) and the 'free' ice cream samples are small and generic.

red_flags.evidence: "It's a selfie factory disguised as culture. Zero educational value." (New York Times)
"The sprinkle pool is full of hair and bandaids. Disgusting." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Designed perfectly for your TikTok feed. Colors are popping." (Influencer Blog)
"My 6-year-old loved the slide and the pink room." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Overpriced photo booth. The ice cream was mediocre. Felt gross in the pool.
If you want cute photos, it's great. If you want ice cream, go to Van Leeuwen.

entries.embedding_text: Museum of Ice Cream in New York, USA. attraction. tourist_trap. 'Selfie factory' with colorful backdrops and plastic sprinkle pool. Not a museum. Expensive tickets, generic ice cream samples. Red flags: Not a museum, Sprinkle pool grossness. Positives: Visual candy, Fun for kids.

entries.name: Gordon Ramsay Hell's Kitchen
entries.summary: A theme park restaurant for fans of the TV show. While the Beef Wellington is consistent, the prices are sky-high for what is essentially a chain restaurant experience. You are paying for the logo and the pitchfork decor.

red_flags.evidence: "$70 for a piece of beef in puff pastry because Ramsay's face is on the menu." (Eater Vegas)
"It feels like an assembly line. Food comes out too fast to be special." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The Wellington is cooked perfectly every time. Reliable." (Food Blog)
"Fun if you love the show. The kitchen layout matches the set." (Yelp)

sample_reviews.text: The scallops were rubbery. Just a marketing gimmick.
Bucket list for my husband. Food was good, bill was painful.

entries.embedding_text: Gordon Ramsay Hell's Kitchen in Las Vegas, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Theme park restaurant for TV show fans. Consistent Beef Wellington, but sky-high prices for assembly-line experience. Red flags: Celebrity tax, Mass produced. Positives: Consistent Wellington, Show immersion.

entries.name: Guy Fieri's Vegas Kitchen
entries.summary: The culinary equivalent of a monster truck rally. The 'Trash Can Nachos' are a viral hit, but the food is excessively greasy, salty, and overpriced. It caters exclusively to tourists wanting excess over quality.

red_flags.evidence: "I felt my arteries clogging. It's just salt and fat." (Yelp)
"$20 for a burger that tastes like Wendy's." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The presentation of the nachos is fun to watch." (Instagram)
"Great place to watch a game and drink huge beers." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Disgusting. The definition of Flavor Town is just salt.
If you have a hangover, this is heaven. Otherwise avoid.

entries.embedding_text: Guy Fieri's Vegas Kitchen in Las Vegas, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Culinary equivalent of a monster truck rally. Viral 'Trash Can Nachos', but food is greasy, salty, and overpriced. Red flags: Grease overload, Expensive junk food. Positives: Trash Can Nachos, Loud fun.

entries.name: Mona Lisa (The Louvre)
entries.summary: While the Louvre is a gem, the Mona Lisa room specifically is a trap. You queue for an hour to get a 30-second glimpse of a tiny painting behind bulletproof glass from 10 feet away, surrounded by hundreds of phones.

red_flags.evidence: "The room is a zoo. People shoving to get a selfie." (Rick Steves)
"It's tiny and dark. The reflection on the glass ruins it." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "It is the most famous face in art history." (Louvre Guide)
"Turn around and look at the Wedding Feast at Cana. It's huge and empty." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Skip the line for Mona. Go see the Napoleon Apartments instead.
Underwhelming but you have to check the box.

entries.embedding_text: Mona Lisa (The Louvre) in Paris, France. attraction. tourist_trap. Specific exhibit trap within a gem museum. Hour-long queues for a distant glimpse of a tiny painting behind glass. Mosh pit atmosphere. Red flags: Mosh pit viewing, Underwhelming reality. Positives: Most famous painting, Rest of museum is amazing.

entries.name: Le Jules Verne (Eiffel Tower)
entries.summary: Dining inside the Eiffel Tower sounds like a trap, but this Michelin-starred restaurant delivers. You get a private elevator, incredible views, and legitimate haute cuisine. Expensive, but offers value by combining entry, view, and fine dining.

red_flags.evidence: "Lunch starts at €140. It is a splurge." (Michelin Guide)
"Book 3 months out. Jacket required." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Skipping the main tower line is worth €50 alone." (Travel Blog)
"Actually delicious, not just 'good for a tower'." (Eater)

sample_reviews.text: The most romantic meal of my life. Food was exquisite.
Expensive but you save time and hassle. Better than the other tower restaurants.

entries.embedding_text: Le Jules Verne (Eiffel Tower) in Paris, France. restaurant. local_gem. Michelin-starred dining inside the tower. Private elevator, incredible views, and legitimate haute cuisine justify the high price. Red flags: Very expensive, Strict dress code. Positives: Private elevator access, Michelin star food.

entries.name: Vatican Museums
entries.summary: Contains some of the world's most important art (Sistine Chapel), but the experience is often miserable due to dangerous overcrowding and heat. It is a 'Must See' that feels like a trap due to mismanagement.

red_flags.evidence: "You are pushed along by the crowd. You cannot stop to look at art." (Guardian)
"People were fainting in the hallways. It is an oven." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The Raphael Rooms and Sistine Chapel are pinnacle human achievements." (Art Forum)
"Pay extra for the 7am Key Master tour to see it empty." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: The art is 10/10, the experience is 0/10. I had a panic attack from the crowd.
Do the Friday night tour. Less people, cooler temperature.

entries.embedding_text: Vatican Museums in Rome, Italy. attraction. mixed. World's most important art collection (Sistine Chapel) ruined by dangerous overcrowding and heat. 'Must See' that feels like a trap. Red flags: Cattle herding, No AC in summer. Positives: Unrivaled art collection, Early access tours work.

entries.name: U Fleků
entries.summary: Prague's oldest brewpub (1499). While the dark lager is historic and good, the venue is infamous for the 'Becherovka scam', where waiters place shots on your table without asking and then charge you for them.

red_flags.evidence: "Waiters drop trays of shots. If you touch it, you pay €5. Aggressive." (Honest Guide)
"Staff shout at you to tip. Very hostile." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The beer is brewed on site and is delicious. Only available here." (Beer Advocate)
"The building is 500 years old and looks it. Accordion music is fun." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Beer is great, food is average. Watch out for the shot guy!
Trap. Locals go to Lokál instead for fresh beer and honest service.

entries.embedding_text: U Fleků in Prague, Czech Republic. restaurant. tourist_trap. Oldest brewpub (1499). Historic dark lager is good, but infamous for 'Becherovka scam' (charging for unordered shots) and rude service. Red flags: Unordered shots scam, Rude service. Positives: Historic dark lager, Medieval hall.

entries.name: Charles Bridge
entries.summary: A stunning medieval bridge that is completely unusable during the day. It is a gauntlet of cheap souvenir stalls, caricaturists, and pickpockets. You cannot see the statues for the crowds.

red_flags.evidence: "You shuffle across. It takes 30 minutes to walk 500 meters." (Prague Morning)
"The 'artists' sell mass-produced junk. Ruins the vibe." (Honest Guide)

positive_signals.evidence: "Go at 5am. The mist on the river is unforgettable." (NatGeo)
"The blackened statues and Gothic towers are masterpieces." (UNESCO)

sample_reviews.text: Avoid between 9am and 9pm. It's a shopping mall on a bridge.
We went at dawn and had it to ourselves. One of the best moments of the trip.

entries.embedding_text: Charles Bridge in Prague, Czech Republic. attraction. tourist_trap. Medieval bridge unusable during day due to crowds and trinket stalls. Gauntlet of pickpockets. Red flags: Impassable crowds, Cheap trinket stalls. Positives: Magical at sunrise, Architectural icon.

entries.name: Széchenyi Thermal Bath
entries.summary: The iconic yellow baths are the largest in Europe. While visually stunning, they are often dirty (hair in water), overcrowded, and confusing to navigate. 'Sparties' (bath parties) at night are notorious tourist traps.

red_flags.evidence: "Water was murky and full of floating hair. Changing rooms smelled." (TripAdvisor)
"Staff yell at you. Signs are unclear. Buying a ticket is a battle." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Soaking in the outdoor pool surrounded by Neo-Baroque palace is epic." (Lonely Planet)
"Nothing else like it. Playing chess in the water is a memory." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Go to Rudas or Gellert instead. Cleaner and less crowded.
Gross changing rooms but the outdoor pool photo is worth it.

entries.embedding_text: Széchenyi Thermal Bath in Budapest, Hungary. attraction. mixed. Iconic yellow baths. Visually stunning and unique, but often dirty, overcrowded, and confusing. 'Sparties' are traps. Red flags: Dirty water, Confusing and rude. Positives: Architectural beauty, Unique experience.

entries.name: Szimpla Kert
entries.summary: The original 'Ruin Bar'. Yes, it is full of tourists, but it is so massive, weird, and culturally significant that it transcends trap status. The decor (old trabant cars, bathtubs) is genuine art, and Sunday farmers markets are lovely.

red_flags.evidence: "Line down the street on weekends. Go early." (Budapest Flow)
"Drinks cost more here than other ruin bars, but entry is free." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Every corner is an art installation. It birthed a genre." (Vice)
"On Sunday mornings, locals sell cheese and honey here. Totally different vibe." (We Love Budapest)

sample_reviews.text: Must see. Even if you don't drink, just walk through.
Crowded with Brits at night, but still the king of ruin bars.

entries.embedding_text: Szimpla Kert in Budapest, Hungary. bar. local_gem. The original 'Ruin Bar'. Massive, weird, and culturally significant. Decor is art. Sunday farmers markets are authentic. Red flags: Nightly queue, Pricier drinks. Positives: Unmatched decor, Sunday Market.

entries.name: Roberta's (Bushwick)
entries.summary: The pizzeria that put Bushwick on the map. Despite becoming a global brand, the original bunker-like location remains excellent. The 'Bee Sting' pizza is iconic, and the hipster-industrial vibe is authentic to the neighborhood.

red_flags.evidence: "2 hour wait on weekends. No reservations for small groups." (Infatuation)
"Deep in Brooklyn. A trek for tourists staying in Manhattan." (Lonely Planet)

positive_signals.evidence: "Sopressata and honey combo is legendary." (Eater NY)
"Tiki bar in the back, garden, radio station. It's a compound." (The New Yorker)

sample_reviews.text: The pizza lives up to the hype. Dough is chewy and charred.
Don't wait 2 hours. Go to the Domino Park outpost if you just want the food.

entries.embedding_text: Roberta's (Bushwick) in New York, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Pizzeria that put Bushwick on the map. 'Bee Sting' pizza is iconic. Hipster-industrial vibe is authentic. Red flags: Long waits, Out of the way. Positives: Bee Sting Pizza, Cool vibe.

entries.name: In-N-Out Burger
entries.summary: The definitive West Coast fast food. Tourists flock to it, but so do locals, chefs, and celebrities. The menu never changes, the prices are incredibly low, and the ingredients are fresh. A rare hype-beast that delivers.

red_flags.evidence: "Drive-thru can take 30 minutes. It wraps around the block." (LA Times)
"The fries are bad unless you get them 'Animal Style' or well-done." (Serious Eats)

positive_signals.evidence: "Double-Double for under $5 is the best deal in LA." (Eater LA)
"Secret menu items transform the meal." (Thrillist)

sample_reviews.text: It's just a burger, but it's a perfect burger for the price.
Fries taste like cardboard. Burger is fresh though.

entries.embedding_text: In-N-Out Burger in Los Angeles, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Definitive West Coast fast food. Menu never changes, prices are low, ingredients fresh. Fries are polarizing. Red flags: Drive-thru lines, Polarizing fries. Positives: Cheap, Animal Style.

entries.name: Russ & Daughters
entries.summary: An appetizing shop (now with a cafe) serving the city's best smoked fish since 1914. It is pricey, but the quality of the lox, caviar, and herring is the benchmark for New York Jewish food.

red_flags.evidence: "Wait can be an hour just to buy bagels. Take a number." (NY Times)
"$20 for a bagel sandwich is steep, but it's loaded with fish." (Infatuation)

positive_signals.evidence: "The Gaspé Nova is silky, smoky perfection." (Bon Appetit)
"100 years of history in every bite. The staff are pros." (Serious Eats)

sample_reviews.text: The Super Heebster bagel is the best sandwich I've ever had.
Cafe wait was 2 hours. Go to the counter instead and eat in the park.

entries.embedding_text: Russ & Daughters in New York, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Smoked fish institution since 1914. Pricey with long waits, but lox and herring are the benchmark for NY Jewish food. Red flags: Take-a-number wait, Premium pricing. Positives: Best lox in NYC, Family owned icon.

entries.name: Naschmarkt
entries.summary: Vienna's most famous market. The central aisle is a tourist trap of aggressive vendors selling overpriced falafel and olives. However, the Saturday Flea Market is legendary, and the perimeter restaurants (like NENI) are solid.

red_flags.evidence: "Vendors shove falafel in your face and demand you buy." (Vienna Unwrapped)
"Cheese and spices are double the supermarket price." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The antique market on Saturdays is a treasure hunt. Real vintage." (Lonely Planet)
"Sitting with a glass of Grüner Veltliner watching the crowd is nice." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Avoid the central lane. Just tourists being ripped off on olives.
NENI was delicious. Great Israeli food in the middle of the market.

entries.embedding_text: Naschmarkt in Vienna, Austria. market. mixed. Vienna's famous market. Central aisle is a trap with aggressive vendors and overpriced goods. Saturday Flea Market and perimeter restaurants are excellent. Red flags: Aggressive sampling, Overpriced goods. Positives: Saturday Flea Market, Wine bars.

entries.name: Samurai Restaurant (formerly Robot Restaurant)
entries.summary: The successor to the famous Robot Restaurant, operating in the same Kabukicho location. Like the original, it's a neon-soaked cabaret with giant props and loud music. It is a pure tourist spectacle with steep ticket prices and zero cultural depth.

red_flags.evidence: "The bento box was cold, sad, and expensive. Eat beforehand." (Japan Guide)
"8000 Yen for a 90 minute show is steep." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's like being inside a seizure. Unique to Tokyo." (Travel Blog)
"The performers give 110%. It is wildly entertaining trash." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: The wildest thing I've ever seen. Don't eat the food, just drink beer and scream.
Headache inducing trap. Just a loud light show.

entries.embedding_text: Samurai Restaurant (formerly Robot Restaurant) in Tokyo, Japan. attraction. tourist_trap. Successor to Robot Restaurant. Neon-soaked cabaret with giant props. Loud, chaotic, and culturally shallow. Pure tourist spectacle. Red flags: Inedible food, Expensive ticket. Positives: Visual overload, High energy.

entries.name: Aguas Calientes Restaurants
entries.summary: The town at the base of Machu Picchu is a captive market. Restaurants serve overpriced, mediocre alpaca pizzas and burgers to exhausted hikers. Service fees are often hidden, and quality is uniformly low.

red_flags.evidence: "Prices are 3x higher than Cusco for terrible food." (Lonely Planet)
"They frequently add a 10-20% 'service' charge plus cover charge that wasn't on the menu." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's the only place to eat after the train." (Travel Blog)
"Some spots have nice views of the rushing river." (Google Maps)

sample_reviews.text: Worst meal in Peru. Frozen pizza for $20. Total rip off.
We found a decent bakery (Boulangerie de Paris) but the rest is trash.

entries.embedding_text: Aguas Calientes Restaurants in Aguas Calientes, Peru. restaurant. tourist_trap. Town at base of Machu Picchu. Captive market with overpriced, mediocre food (alpaca pizza). Hidden fees are common. Red flags: Captive market pricing, Hidden taxes. Positives: Convenience, River views.

entries.name: Lombard Street
entries.summary: The 'crookedest street in the world' is actually a traffic jam of rental cars. Residents hate the tourists who climb on their porches. It is a pretty photo, but driving down it is a stressful 45-minute wait for a 30-second descent.

red_flags.evidence: "Line of cars blocks the neighborhood. Idling fumes everywhere." (SF Gate)
"Residents are trying to charge a toll to discourage visitors." (CNN)

positive_signals.evidence: "View from the top looking at Coit Tower is spectacular." (TripAdvisor)
"The hydrangeas are beautiful in bloom." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Don't drive it. Walk it early in the morning. Driving is a trap.
Underwhelming. Just a curvy road with too many people.

entries.embedding_text: Lombard Street in San Francisco, USA. attraction. tourist_trap. 'Crookedest street' is a traffic jam of rental cars. Residents hate the nuisance. Driving is stressful; walking offers better views. Red flags: Traffic nightmare, Nuisance. Positives: Great views, Flower gardens.

entries.name: La Rambla Outdoor Restaurants
entries.summary: The rows of outdoor terraces on La Rambla serve giant glasses of 'Sangria' (sugar and cheap wine) and 'Paellaador' (frozen industrial paella). It is the classic European tourist trap strip.

red_flags.evidence: "If you see photos of food on the menu, run. It's microwaved." (Culinary Backstreets)
"They serve you a 'bulldog' size drink without asking and charge €25." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Sitting under the trees watching the world go by is nice." (Lonely Planet)
"Right in the middle of the action." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Avoid like the plague. Go to El Glop for real Paella.
Food was rubbery and tasteless. Waiter was rude when we didn't tip big.

entries.embedding_text: La Rambla Outdoor Restaurants in Barcelona, Spain. restaurant. tourist_trap. Outdoor terraces serve frozen industrial paella and overpriced giant Sangrias. Classic European trap. Red flags: Frozen Paella, Giant drink scam. Positives: People watching, Central.
